fields.title: Git & GitHub Introduction
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

Version Control System (VCS) is one of the most critical tools for coding and digital application development. Git is the most commonly used version control system, created by Linus Torvalds in 2005 for the development of the Linux kernel. GitHub is one of the most popular remote repository services based on the Git platform.

In this course, we’ll explain how to use Git as a version control system and how to collaborate on GitHub .

 

Icons

Throughout the course, we are uzing some icons to improve clarity of topics.

Git and GitHub icons

  • You can find the Git icon (  ) or GitHub icon (  ) on top right of each main slide. The icons are indications of which platform's explanations are covered on the page. If both icons are shown, the page explain both topics or intersections of the two platforms.

Practice Section (  )

  • We prepared a practice section on some pages to demonstrate key commands and operations on the web browser . The demonstration is based on MacOS computer, however, the demonstration is also largely applicable to other OS like Windows and Linux.
  • To make clear how you need to use the command line or text editor, we use the following icons before the black box to describe code or command.
    •  : when you see this icon, you need to make inputs on the command line based on the instruction.
    •    : this icon indicates that the descriptions below the icon is responses in the command line after your command line input
    •    : in some case, the command line requires interactive session, for example, when it is asking your password. This icon indicates that you need to make inputs based on the command line's request.
    •   : when you write code or make a commit message for Git, you need a text editor. This icon indicates that the descriptions below the icon need to be written in your text editor.
  • You can find pages which have a practice section through main slides. If there is this icon () in the bottom left of the slide, the page includes practice section.

fields.title: Chapter 1.  Git & GitHub Key Concepts
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll explain the key concepts of Git and remote repository services using GitHub examples. The following topics are covered in this chapter.

TOPICS

  1. What Is Git?
  2. What Is Version Control?
  3. How To Make A Record On Git?
  4. Collaborating On Git & GitHub — Remote Repository
  5. Collaborating On Git & GitHub — Branch
  6. What You Can Do On GitHub Beyond Coding Collaboration

 

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: What Is Git?
fields.content:
Git is a free and open-source distributed version control system. Git is often used with remote repository services such as GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket. Git and remote repository services like GitHub can provide Three Key Values.

Three Key Values

  1. Version Control: using Git, you can record, track and retrieve your coding histories
  2. Collaborative Coding: on Git and remote repository services, you can share your code, get others’ codes and work as a team
  3. Task Management & Automation: most Git remote repository services provide additional features to manage tasks and automate workflow such as auto deployment.

Git and Github are often explained together, however, they are different things. Git is a version control system while GitHub is a repository service provided by GitHub, Inc. Typically, remote repository services also offer task management features. For example, GitHub provides Git Issues that allows you to input tasks and share them with your team. GitHub or other remote repository services can also integrate with other services for workflow automation.

fields.title: What Is Version Control?
fields.content:
When coding, you need to manage several files which are dependent on one another. If you want to save different versions, you need to save entire sets of files in different directories with version names. This approach is very computer resource consuming. Git provides solutions for this with simple Git commands.

There are two keywords to understand the Git coding history management: Repository and Commit.

Repository is a location where different versions of codes are stored. There are two types of repositories:

  • Local Repository: it is installed on your local computer
  • Remote Repository: it is created under a remote repository service platform such as GitHub on the Internet.

Commit creates a snapshop to record the status of coding in a repository. Only committed files are recorded in the Git log system. Committed files are saved with the following key information:

  • Commit hash: unique number to identify each commit
  • Author information: name and email address of the person who made the commit
  • Date and time
  • Commit message: short title and description about the commit

fields.title: How To Make A Record On Git?
fields.content:
Git allows us to track all changes in our working files, however it doesn’t record every single change. Git tracks only Committed files (a snapshot of set of project files). This is like when we save a file on our computer as one version and save again as another version with different filenames.

Committed files are stored in a local or remote repository. Through the remote repository, you can share your work and collaborate with others. Here we’ll explain how to manage working history under a local repository.

There are three major areas to manage versions through Git. 

  • Working Tree is used to edit your working files. The files and directories which you see on your working directory are Working Tree. Here you can edit your files. 
  • Staging Area is a buffer area used to prepare your working files for commit. The command to bring the working files into Staging Area is $ git add. You can double check if the files you added to Staging Area are ready for commit. If the files are ready, you can commit and save them under Local Repository. The command to commit files is $ git commit.
  • Local Repository is a place where Committed files are stored with version histories. By running $ git commit command, you can commit your files under Staging Area (save a version under your Local Repository). At this stage, your files are still on your computer and not accessible for others. To share the files, you need to bring the files to Remote Repository, which is explained on the next page

When committing files, you need to write a message describing what the commit is about: for example, "added payment function" or "fixed errors".

When running the $ git commit command, a text editor launches automatically for writing comments. Vim text editor is the default setting typically. For the purpose of this course, Visual Studio Code will be used.

More details will be provided in Chapter 5 Edit & Commit.

fields.title: Collaborating On Git&Git Hub ‚Äî Remote Repository
fields.content:
Collaborative coding is typically managed through a Remote Repository. A Remote Repository is a place where Committed files are stored on the web and can be shared with others. GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket are the major remote repository services. 

Interactions between a Local Repository and Remote Repository are done through the command line on a local computer or a desktop application provided by remote repository services.

The following steps are an example flow to share the files and collaborate with a team member.

Example: Developer A initiates a project, and Developer B supports Developer A

  1. Developer A works on coding and makes the first Commit (saved in his Local Repository).
  2. Developer A sends the commited files to his Remote Repository. This action is called Push. The command to push files is $ git push.
  3. Developer A gives Developer B access to his Remote Repository.
  4. Developer B brings the files from the Remote Repository to her local computer. When she does this for the first time, the action is called Clone. Clone creates the same set of files as the Remote Repository in the local computer — commited files are registered in her Local Repository and the same files are saved under the working directory. The command to clone is $ git clone.
  5. Developer B can work on creating new lines of code and save them under her Local Repository (Commit).
  6. Developer B pushes them back to Remote Repository where Developer A can access them. 
  7. Developer A can bring the files back to his Local Repository and his working directory. This action is called Pull. The command to pull files is $ git pull.

The flow above is one of typical case. We’ll give more details about Remote Repository in Chapter 7 Remote Collaboration.

fields.title: Collaborating On Git&Git Hub ‚Äî Branch
fields.content:
A Branch in Git is an independent line of development with a comit history. Different branches give a different recording space; each branch has its own coding history (a line of commits). 

Branches allow us to manage different versions of the same set of project files simultaneously. For example, one developer can work on adding a new promotion campaign feature while another developer is working on adding a new payment feature to the same web application. 

Git provides a master branch as a default. Unless you create a new branch, all your work is done on the master branch. The branch to create a new feature is typically called a topic branch. 

Once development is completed in a topic branch, you can merge it with the master branch or its parent branch. 

With the branching functionality, you can collaborate with others efficiently. Or even you can utilize branches by yourself to manage versions to develop different features simultaniously.

More details of the Branch concept and operations will be explained in Chapter 6 Work with Branches.

fields.title: What You Can Do Beyond Collaborative Coding On GitHub
fields.content:
GitHub is no longer just a Git hosting service. There are several features you can use. Here are some examples. 

GitHub Issues: this is a task management tool. GitHub users can easily create project task lists using GitHub Issues. You can upload images by simple drag&drop and add an image in the issue list very easily. GitHub issues is a powerful tool for communicating with your team members effectively.  You can also asign your team members to each task.

GitHub Actions: this is a tool to support CI/CD and DevOps workflow. Even before GitHub Actions was introduced, GitHub was a popular platform for CI/CD and DevOps through API, connecting with other applications such as CircleCI, Travis CI, Jenkins. GitHub Actions give you more opportunities to improve your workflow within your repositories on GitHub.

GitHub also provides other tools and services like auto security alerts using Dependabot. 

Several client apps are also available to improve your working efficiencies.

  GitHub Desktop: To control GitHub on a local GUI application

  GitHub CLI: To control GitHub from the local computer's command line.

  GitHub Mobile App: To easily check status of issues and repositories 

Some details will be provided in Chapter 8 Supplemental Topics.

fields.title: Chapter 2.   Git & GitHub Life Cycle
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll go through a typical user journey with explanations of basic Git commands and GitHub features. This chapter covers the following topics.

TOPICS

  1. Git & GitHub Basic Life Cycle Overview
  2. Target State Of Git Project Launch
  3. Git & GitHub Regular Workflow

 

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: Git & GitHub Basic Life Cycle Overview
fields.content:
Beginners of Git and GitHub should understand Five Key Steps.

The first two steps are for a preparation to start a project on Git and GitHub. 

Step 1: Initial Settings

When you first use Git and GitHub, you need to install Git software and register your profile. You also need to create a GitHub account. This is a one-time operation unless you want to change your computer or your account. The details will be covered in Chapter 3.

Step 2: Launch a project

When you initiate a project, you need to create local and remote repositories that will be used to save your coding and share your codes with others. At this step, you’ll also establish a connection between the local repository and the remote repository. The details will be covered in Chapter 4.

 

The last three steps cover daily operations on Git and GitHub. Throughout your coding project, you are expected to use various Git commands and GitHub features on a daily basis along with the following three steps.

Step 3: Edit & Commit

Once you launched a project, you can start to write and edit your code. You can save several versions of code in your Local Repository by committing the codes. The details will be covered in Chapter 5.

Step 4: Work with Branches

When you add some features while continuing working on the main code development, you may want to develop several versions of code simultaniously. The Branch functionality enables you or your team members to work on different versions of code simultaneously. The details will be covered in Chapter 6.

Step 5: Remote Collaboration

One of the key features of Git is that it allows collaboration with others. You can share your code through remote repository with your team members and vice versa. The details will be covered in Chapter 7.

fields.title: Target State Of Git Project Launch
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

The target of the first two steps described on the previous page is to establish the illustrated status for a specific project.

  • A Local Repository for the project is created on your local computer
  • A Remote Repository for the project is created on GitHub and / or access to the project Remote Repository is granted to the necessary project members
  • The Local Repository and Remote Repository are linked with each other (typically through HTTPS or SSH connection)

At this stage, you should be able to see the same directories and files in both Local Repository and Remote Repository. Once you reach this status, you are ready to start a new project with Git & GitHub and you can move on to the regular Git & GitHub workflow explained on the next page.

fields.title: Git & GitHub Regular Workflow
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

In the regular Git & GitHub workflow, you repeat three types of actions typically.

  • Edit & Commit codes (register in a Local Repository)
  • Work with Branches to develop codes simultaniously
  • Remote collaboration by sharing codes with other team members through a Remote Repository

To master Git & GitHub workflow,  you need to learn various Git commands and some GitHub features. In Chapter 5, 6 and 7, we will go through each command and feature one by one.

fields.title: Chapter 3. Git & GitHub Initial Settings
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll explain how to set up Git and GitHub. This chapter covers the following topics. 

TOPICS

  1. Git & GitHub Initial Settings Overview 
  2. Install Git
  3. Git User Settings — Git Config
  4. Create GitHub Account
  5. GitHub Access Authentication Settings
  6. Generating PAT (Personal Access Token)
  7. GitHub SSH Setup

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: Git & GitHub Initial Settings Overview
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

The goal of this chapter is to help you understand how to set up Git on your local computer and conduct initial settings for GitHub from its website. 

To set up Git & GitHub, you need to take the following four key steps.

Step 1: Install Git

To use Git on your computer, you need to download and install it first. Installation approaches differ by OS (Mac OS, Windows and Linux).

Step 2: Git User Settings

As Git is a tool to record coding histories including author of edits, you need to register your basic information (i.e., user name and email address). You can also register your preferred text editor which is used when you make commit messages.

Step 3: GitHub Signup

To use GitHub, you need to sign up for the GitHub service on its website. GitHub provides a free plan. You can start with the free plan for learning purposes. 

Step 4: GitHub Access Authentication Settings

To access GitHub from the command line, you need to have authentication settings. Common authentication approaches for GitHub are HTTPS and SSH. For HTTPS, you need to generate PAT (Personal Access Token) to use it as a password to access a Remote Repository.

fields.title: Install Git
fields.content:
As Git is open source software (OSS), anyone can install and use it.

Git is available on Git's official site ( https://git-scm.com/ ). 

If Git is not installed onto your computer, download a relevant OS version and install it onto your computer. 

For Mac: 

 

Git is typically pre-installed on Mac.

Check the Git version with the $ git --version command.

If the command line returns a version, Git is already installed onto your computer.

If Git is not installed, follow the instructions below.

There are several options to install Git onto your computer.

The most popular one is Home Brew. Here are the steps to install Git with Home Brew:

1. Install Home Brew if you don’t have it on your computer. 

You can check if you have Home Brew on your computer by running the $ brew -- version command

If Home Brew is not installed yet, run the following command (copy the code and past it in the command line):

$ /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

See more details about Home Brew here: ( https://brew.sh/ )

2. Install Git
To install Git with Home Brew, run the following command

$ brew install git

To see other options to install Git onto Mac, go to this page: https://git-scm.com/download/mac

For Windows: 

 

To install Git onto Windows computer, follow the steps below.

1. Go to this site https://git-scm.com/downloads

2. Click Windows. The Git installation package will be downloaded onto your computer.

3. Open the downloaded .exe file

4. Follow the installation instructions. Unless you want to change the setting, keep pressing the Next buttom.

For Linux: 

 

A typical approach to install Git onto Linux computers is through the Linux command line.

Installation commands differ by Linux distributions. If you are using Debian/Ubuntu, you can use the apt-get command. 

$ sudo apt-get update 
$ sudo apt-get install git

For other Linux distributions, please refer to the following link.

http://git-scm.com/download/linux

 

1. Check git version

Run the following command. If Git is installed already, the command line returns a version.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git --version

If Git is already installed, you can skip the following steps and go to next page. If your Git version is old, you can also reinstall Git with a newer version by following the steps below.

2. Check if Home Brew is installed

Run the following command. If Home Brew is installed already, the command line returns a version.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ brew --version

If Home Brew is already installed, you can skip step 3 and go to step 4.

3. Install Home Brew

To install Home Brew, copy the following installation command and paste onto terminal.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

During the installation process, your computer password may be required.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

==> Checking for `sudo` access (which may request your password)...

Input your computer password.

 Command Line - INPUT

Password: YOUR PASSWORD

Installation starts as follows.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

==> This script will install:
/usr/local/bin/brew

If permissions are not properly set, you may see the following error message.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Error: Can't create update lock in /usr/local/var/homebrew/locks!
Fix permissions by running:
  sudo chown -R $(whoami) /usr/local/var/homebrew
Failed during: /usr/local/bin/brew update --force --quiet

Following the instruction, run this command

 Command Line - INPUT

$sudo chown -R $(whoami) /usr/local/var/homebrew

Because of this error, the installation process is cancelled.

In that case, you need to run the same installation command ($ /bin/bash -c "$(curl... ) again.

If you finally get the following message, Home Brew is successfully installed onto your computer. You can move on to the next.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

==> Installation successful!

4. Install Git

To install Git, run the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ brew install git

or

$ brew reinstall git

You may get an error message.  A typical error is the access permission error. Update permission based on the instructions described in the error message. Then, run the installation command again.

The following is an example of the command line response when Git is successfully installed or upgraded.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

git 2.33.1_1 is already installed but outdated
==> Downloading https://ghcr.io/v2/homebrew/core/git/manifests/2.34.1
Already downloaded: /Users/bloovee/Library/Caches/Homebrew/downloads/xxx
==> Downloading https://ghcr.io/v2/homebrew/core/git/blobs/xxxx
Already downloaded: /Users/bloovee/Library/Caches/Homebrew/downloads/xxx
==> Upgrading git
  2.33.1_1 -> 2.34.1

    :

Emacs Lisp files have been installed to:
  /usr/local/share/emacs/site-lisp/git
==> Summary
üç∫  /usr/local/Cellar/git/2.34.1: 1,513 files, 42.7MB

Now your are ready to use Git on your Mac computer.

fields.title: Git User Settings ‚Äî Git Config
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

The next step after Git installation is registering user profiles on Git. On this page, you'll learn the following five items relating to the Git configulations.

  1. Register your user name and email address
  2. Register a text editor
  3. Check configured settings
  4. Clear configured settings

1. Register username and email address

Git tracks who made changes. To track change history with editor information, you need to register your username and email address first before using Git.

To register a username, type and run the following code in your command prompt.

$ git config --global user.name [your username]

To register an email address, run the following code.

$ git config --global user.email [your email address]

 

Note:

The "--global" option is to apply the settings to the user of the computer. If you don't use the option, the settings are registered only to the Local Repository you are working on.

 

2. Register a text editor

When hitting Git commit, you need to add notes in the text editor. The default text editor is normally vim, however, using a more advanced text editor increases your productivity. Some text editors can be integrated with GitHub to build more seamless operations.

To register your text editor, run the following command.

$ git config --global core.editor ‚Äú[editor path] --wait‚Äù

In this course, we'll use Visual Studio Code (VSC). “code” is the editor path of VSC. To use the path, it also needs to be registered on your computer when installing VSC.

3. Check user settings

 To confirm the setting, you need to run the following code.

$ git config --list

4. Unset user settings

The settings you made can be modified. Use the --unset option to clear your settings, and register new settings. For example, if you want to change your username in the Git configuration, run the following code to unset your username.

$ git config --global ‚Äîunset user.name

 

1. Register your username and email address

To register user name and email address, run the following code. Using bloovee account as an example.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git config --global user.name bloovee
$ git config --global user.email bloovee@email.com

You can see your username and email address are successfully registered by running the $ git config --list command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git config --list

You’ll see the status of username and email setting like the one below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

user.name=bloovee
user.email=bloovee@email.com

 

2. Register your text editor

Next, register your text editor. In this case, registering Visual Studio Code (VSC). "code" is the editor path of VSC.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git config --global core.editor "code --wait"

Check the status by the $ git config --list command, and you’ll see that the editor is also registered like the one below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

user.name=bloovee
user.email=bloovee@email.com
core.editor=code --wait

 

3. Unset user settings

Deregister username, email and text editor by runnig the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git config --global --unset user.name
$ git config --global --unset user.email
$ git config --global --unset core.editor

Check the status by the $ git config --list command, and you’ll see that all the settings are cleared.

fields.title: Create GitHub Account
fields.content:
The next step for the initial setup is to create an account on a remote repository service. Here we’ll explain how to setup a GitHub account.

 

1. Go to the GitHub official site and click “Sign up” on the top right

https://github.com

 

2. Enter your email, password and username

You’ll also need to answer some questions.

 

3. Verify your email account

After you register username, email address and password, a pass code will be sent to your email address. You will need to enter the pass code on the site.

 

4. Choose your account plan

Usually, the free plan is enough for learning purposes.

 

5. Optional: set up your user icon

User icon is auto-generated as an initial setting. You can replace it with your own icon or picture. To set up your user icon, 

— select + on the menu bar on top

— select Settings

— select Profiles

— select Edit and click the Upload a photo button

— select an image from your computer to upload

It may take a few minutes to replace the icon images.

fields.title: GitHub Access Authentication Settings
fields.content:
You can access remote repositories on GitHub from the command line in two ways: HTTPS and SSH. When you clone the repository or establish remote settings, you can choose the method of authentication by your URL choice. Git provides different URLs of a remote repository for HTTPS and SSH.

HTTPS

HTTPS uses username and PAT (Personal Access Token) as an account verification approach. Previously, we used GitHub password instead of PAT. To enhance security, GitHub introduced PAT. You need to generate PAT priort to using HTTPS. HTTPS is considered faster than SSH and you can work with all repositories on GitHub over HTTPS usually, even if you are behind a firewall or proxy. The way to generate PAT is explained on the next page.

SSH

SSH uses a pair of secret key and public key. You need to generate a key pair and upload the public key onto the GitHub account site. SSH can be slower than HTTPS, however, you can add several settings using the config file. Firewalls and proxys might refuse to allow SSH connections. In that case, you need to add proxy server settings in the Git system. The way to add SSH settings in GitHub is explained later.

fields.title: Generating PAT (Personal Access Token)
fields.content:
In order to establish HTTPS connection, you’ll need PAT (Personal Access Token).

Here we’ll explain how to set up PAT.

 

1. Log into GitHub and go to user settings

Go to GitHub website, click your icon and press the Settings button.

 

2. Move to Developer Settings page

Go to the the bottom of the page and select Developer settings

 

3. Generate a new token

Select Personal access tokens and press the Generate new token button.

Add Note (describe what the token is for?) and set Expiration. After the token is expired, you need to generate another token.

In the Select scopes section, you need to check repo to get access to your private remote repositories. You can add other scopes later when required.

Press the Generate token button.

When a new token is successfully generated, you’ll see your PAT. Make sure you’ll copy it and save it somewhere as it won't be shown again.

 

4. Prepare for HTTPS connection

To establish HTTPS connections going forward, go to your repository on GitHub and press the Code button. Make sure to select the HTTPS tab to get the URL for HTTPS. (the URL for SSH is different)

When you clone, push or pull, you’ll be asked your username and password. You need to use PAT instead of GitHub password. Previously, it was GitHub password, however, GitHub changed the rule to strengthen security level. How to establish HTTPS connection will be explained in the later chapters along with the key git commands: $ git clone, $ git remote, $ git push and $ git pull.

fields.title: GitHub SSH Setup
fields.content:
To establish SSH connection, you need to do the following four steps

 

1. Generate an SSH key pair

 By running the following command, a key pair (secret key and public key) is generated. 

$ ssh-keygen -t rsa -C ‚Äúyour email address‚Äù

When running the command, you’ll be asked to set passphrase. Type your passphrase twice. Save the passphrase as the passphrase is used when you establish ssh connection.

 

Note:

-t option is to set security type. Default is rsa.

-C option is to overwrite a comment in the key. As the default comment is username@hostname, it is good to overwrite to avoid disclosing your hostname. Typically, email address is used for the comment.

 

2. Copy the public key

 For Mac, show public key content by running the $ cat command. For windows, you can use the $ type command.

$ cat file_path

 Copy the public key infomation (begining with ssh-rsa and ending with your email address)

 You can use the $ pbcopy command for Mac or the $ clip command for windows to directly copy the content of the file.

$ pbcopy file_path

 

3. Upload the public key to GitHub

You need to upload the copied public key to GitHub account setting page by conducting the following actions.

— Go to the GitHub website

— Click your icon

— Press the Settings button

— Select SSH and GPG keys on the left side bar

— Press New SSH key button

— Fill title name (any name) and paste the public key information

 

4. Test connection with GitHub

 Run the following command and type your passphrase.

$ ssh -T git@github.com

After entering the passphrase, you can see a message confirming that you’ve been successfully authenticated

 

1. Generate an SSH key pair

Run the $ ssh-keygen command

 Command Line - INPUT

$ ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "bloovee@example.com"

After running the command, you’ll be asked the file path to save the key like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Generating public/private rsa key pair.
Enter file in which to save the key (/Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa):

Hit the return key (typicaly, it's saved under the .ssh directory in the indication above).

Next, you’ll be asked to enter a passphrase like below. The passphrase is a password to confirm that the key is owned by you when establishing ssh connection. Ensure that you’ll type the same passphrase twice and save it somewhere for future use.

 Command Line - INTERACTIVE

Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase): TYPE YOUR PASSPHRASE
Enter same passphrase again: TYPE YOUR PASSPHRASE

Once the passphrase is set, a key pair is saved under the file path displayed. You'll see the following response in your command line window.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Your identification has been saved in /Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa.
Your public key has been saved in /Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa.pub.
The key fingerprint is:
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx bloovee@example.com
The key's randomart image is:
+---[RSA 3072]----+
|     ooo   . =*O=|
|     .. + o =.O+=|
|    E  . + o.= oo|
         :

You can confirm that the two files are generated in the .ssh directory under your home directory. .ssh directory is a hidden directory. If you cannot see it, you need to make hidden directories and files visible by pressing SHIFT + Command + . (period). 

 

2. Copy the public key

By running the $ cat command with the file path of the public key, the public key information is displayed (starting with ssh-rsa and ending with the email address set when you generated the key).

 Command Line - INPUT

$ cat /Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

 Command Line - RESPONSE

ssh-rsa xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxbloovee@example.com

Copy the entire texts and go to the next step. Instead of the $ cat command, you can also use the $ pbcopy command to directly copy the contents without displaying them.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ pbcopy < /Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa.pub

 

3. Upload the public key to GitHub

Go to the GitHub website, click your icon and press the Settings button

Select the SSH and GPG keys on the left side bar

Press the New SSH key button

Fill title name (any name) in the Title field and paste the public key information in the Key field.

 

4. Test connection with GitHub

 Run the $ ssh command with the GitHub url 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ ssh -T git@github.com

When running the command, you'll be asked a passphrase. Type your passphrase

 Command Line - INTERACTIVE

Enter passphrase for key '/Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa': TYPE YOUR PASSPHRASE

After entering the passphrase, you can see a message confirming that you’ve been successfully authenticated. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Hi bloovee! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.

You are ready to access to GitHub by SSH.

 

To establish SSH connections going forward, go to your repository on GitHub and press the Code button. Make sure to select the SSH tab to get the URL for SSH. The URL for HTTPS is different. More details will be provided in the later chapters.

fields.title: Chapter 4. Launch Git Project
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll explain how to launch a Git project. Topics covered in this chapter are the following

TOPICS

  1. Three Cases To Launch Git Project
  2. Key Steps To Launch Git Project As Project Initiator
  3. Create Local Repository — Git Init
  4. Making The First Commit
  5. .gitignore File
  6. Set UP Remote Repository — Create Repository And Grant Access
  7. Link Remote Repository With Local Repository — Git Remote Add
  8. Upload Local Repository To Remote Repository — Git Push
  9. How To Work With Remote Repository When Launching Project
  10. Case 1. Create Own Repository And Share It With Others
  11. Case 2. Get Access To Others’ Remote Repository As Collaborator
  12. Git Clone
  13. Case 3. Create Replica Of Remote Repository And Bring It To Local Computer
  14. Fork vs. Clone

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: Three Cases To Launch Git Project
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

Typically, there are three cases to launch a Git project depending on who initiates the project and becomes the owner of the Remote Repository.

Three Cases of a Git Project Launch

Case 1. Project initiator: initiates a Git project on the local computer by creating a Local Repository, and set up a Remote Repository to share the project files

Case 2. Project member: participates in a Git project through a Remote Repository on GitHub (being a collaobrator of the Remote Repository)

Case 3. Non-project member: launches a project leveraging existing code in a Remote Repository on GitHub (no collaborator access to the original Remote Repository)

 

Case 1. Project initiator (Owner of the Remote Repository)

In this case, you launch a new Git project from your local computer by initiating a Local Repository yourself. As the project initiator, you also set up a Remote Repository for the project to share the project files. There are four key steps until the project files are ready to be shared on GitHub.

Step 1. Create a Local Repository

As a project initiator, first thing you need to do is to initiate a Local Repository for the project. $ git init is the command to create a new Local Repository.

Step 2. Work with a Local Repository

Until you start to store or share files through Remote Repositories on GitGHub, you work on the project with the Git system on your local computer. We'll explain about typical workflow of Git local operations in the next chapters (Chapter 5: Edit & Commit, Chapter 6: Work with Branches). In this chapter, we'll cover this step briefly.

Step 3. Set up a Remote Repository

When you want to store and share your project files on GitHub, you need to create a new Remote Repository on GitHub. Creating a Remote Repository is done through the GitHub website. You can also invite contributors for the project to give them access to your Remote Repository.

Step 4. Start sharing project files

In this step, we aim to make project files shared through the Remote Repository. Before uploading your project files, you need to establish a link between your Local Repository and your Remote Repository by running the $ git remote add command. To upload the committed files, run the $ git push command. When the files are successfully uploaded, they are ready to be shared with others.

 

Case 2. Project member (Collaborator of the Remote Repository)

In this case, project files and repositories are already prepared by someone. What you need to do to participate in the project are the following two steps.

Step 1. Get access to the Remote Repository

If your team member or your company have a Remote Repository for the project, you need to get access to the Remote Repository where you can access the project files.

Step 2. Clone the Remote Repository

Once you get access to the Remote Repository, you can start to download project files by running the $ git clone command. The $ git clone command brings the project files onto your local computer and creates the Local Repository. The command also establishes a link between the Local Repository and the Remote Repository so that you can start to interact with the Remote Repository from the command line on your computer.

 

Case 3: Non-project member (no collaborator access to the original Remote Repository)

In this case, original project files and repositories are already available on the GitHub platform, however, you are not invited to the project as a collaborator. What you need to do to launch a new project based on the existing project files are the following two steps

Step 1. Create a replica of an existing Remote Repository: Fork

As GitHub is an open platform, you can access many repositories created by someone else. You may want to leverage an existing repository to start your new project. In this case, you need to Fork the existing repository. Fork creates a replica of the existing repository under your GitHub account; the forked repository's owner becomes you.

Step 2. Clone the Remote Repository

As the same as Case 2, you can bring the project files to your local computer by running the $ git clone command.

fields.title: Key Steps To Launch Git Project As Project Initiator
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

On this page onwards, we'll explain about Case 1 on the previou page first as Case 1 is the basis for Case 2 and Case 3. As explained, Case 1 is the case for a project initiator who is launching a Git project on the local computer. The target of a Git project launch in Case 1 is to establish the situation where the project files are shared via a GitHub Remote Repository so that developers in Case 2 and Case 3 can access to the project files.

On the following pages, we'll explain about the four key steps for Case 1 with the Git key commands.

Step 1. Create a Local Repository

  • By running the $ git init command, create a Local Repository in a project directory on the local computer

Step 2. Work with a Local Repository

  • Edit project files and make a commit: the four basic key commands ($ git add, $ git commit, $ git status, $ git log)
  • Utilize .gitignore file: a list of files to be ignored by the Git system)

Step 3. Set up a Remote Repository

  • Create a new repository on GitHub
  • Invite collaborators to the Remote Repository on GitHub

Step 4. Start sharing project files

  • Establish a link between Remote and Local Repositories by registering a URL of the Remote Repository in the Local Repository: $ git remote add
  • Upload project files: $ git push

The first two steps are done on the local computer. If you want to understand the Git operations on the local environment first, you can go through the first two steps and go to Chapter 5 and Chapter 6 to learn more details about the Git local operations.

fields.title: Create Local Repository ‚Äî Git Init
fields.content:
The first step to launch a Git project is run the $ git init command. The command will create a Local Repository in the current directory.

This command doesn't require any options or parameters. You need to simply run the following command in the directory where you want to generate a new project.

$ git init

After running the command, a Local Repository is created under a hidden directory named .git. If you cannot see it, you need to make hidden directories and files visible by pressing SHIFT + Command + . (period). 

 

1. Prepare a directory and a file for this new git project

To launch a project, create a project directory and a file for a practice purpose. Here we'll create a git_practice directory and git_practice.html file 

Run the following command to create them.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ mkdir git_practice
$ cd git_practice
$ touch git_practice.html

 

2. Create a Local Repository

To create a Local Repository, run the $ git init command in the git_practice directory

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git init

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/bloovee/Desktop/git_practice/.git/

After running the command, you can see one hidden directory named .git is created. This is the place where the Local Repository is created.

fields.title: Making The First Commit
fields.content:
Although we’ll provide more details about Git operations on the local computer in the next chapter, in this chapter, we’ll briefly explain the four key commands that will help launch a project and make the first commit.

  • $ git add: with this command, you can add files to the Staging Area, where you can prepare and check files to register in your local repository. 
  • $ git commit: with this command, you can register files in your Local Repository. Once the files are registered by this commit command, you can retrieve the saved version of the set of files anytime.
  • $ git status: with this command, you can see the status of the Working Tree and the Staging Area. This status lets you see which changes have been staged, which haven't, and which files aren't being tracked by Git. 
  • $ git log: with this command, you can see commit histories in a local repository. 

The following practice helps you understand the four key commands.

 

1. Prepare a file for this practice

On the previous page, we already set up a Local Repository, however, nothing is recorded in the repository yet. 

Here, we’ll make a record of the html file (git_practice.html) created on the previous page. As we haven't edited the file yet, let's prepare a dummy code. We'll also use this file in the following pages.

Open the file with a text editor and edit the html file like the following, and save the file.

 Text Editor

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
 <style>
 h1 {
  color:red;
  font-size:80px
 }
 </style>
</head>
<body>
 <h1>Hello World!</h1>
</body>

2. Check how the file is tracked by the Git system

Although the file is saved under the git_practice directory. It is still NOT recorded under the Git repository yet. To check the status, you can run the $ git log command. 

 Command Line - INPUT

 $ git log

You can see the message explaining that nothing has been committed yet like the one below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

fatal: your current branch 'master' does not have any commits yet
Also, if you run the $ git status command, you can see that there is an untracked files.

Also, if you run the $ git status command, you can see that there are untracked files. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git status

 Command Line - RESPONSE

No commits yet
Untracked files:
  (use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)
        .gitignore
        git_practice.html
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)

This means the file exists in the Working Tree, however, it's not registered in the Local Repository or the Staging Area. 

3. Register files in the Staging Area

To register the file in the Local Repository, first run the $ git add command. Make sure you are in the git_practice directory in your command line, and use "." to add all the files under the Current directory.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git add .

At this stage, the files are not registered in the Local Repository yet. Check how the file is tracked by the Git system by running the $ git status command. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git status

 Command Line - RESPONSE

On branch master
No commits yet
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached ..." to unstage)
        new file:   .gitignore
        new file:   git_practice.html

4. Register files in the Local Repository

Run the $ git commit -m “the first commit” command to register the files in the Local Repository. You can add comments to the commit using the -m option. 

If you don’t put this option, a text editor is launched to add comments. In that case, you need to type your comments in the text editor and save it. After closing the editor, you can come back to the command line.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -m ‚Äúthe first commit‚Äù

 Command Line - RESPONSE

[master (root-commit) af14aa0] the first commit
 2 files changed, 10 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 .gitignore
 create mode 100644 git_practice.html

Run the $ git log command again to check the commit status. Now you can see that the html file is registered in the Local Repository.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log

 Command Line - RESPONSE

commit af14aa0387171f8b70d06cb31f84e57648ae2c78 (HEAD -> master)
Author: bloovee <bloovee@example.com>
Date:   XXXXXXXXX

    the first commit

 

TIPS

You may not want Git system to track all your files in the project directory. .gitignore file is a useful tool. The documents or directories listed in the file will be ignored by the Git system. We'll explain about .gitignore file in the next page.

fields.title: .gitignore File
fields.content:
One of the key values of Git is sharing files. There are files or directories which you may not want to share or you don't need to share. For example, environment files may contain a password. If you keep it in your project directory, Git detects the file and it will be stored in the remote repository when you push the project directory into the remote repository. If you are a Mac user, you may see the .DS_Store file as a hidden file in each directory. This file is used to store custom attributes of the folder on your computer, such as the position of icons or the choice of a background image. This file is also not necessary for a coding project and doesn’t require sharing with other developers.

To exclude those files from the Git version control system, Git uses the .gitignore file. The files and directories written in the .gitignore file are excluded from the Git version control system.

Besides the .env file and OS specific files, log files and package files are also typically written in the .gitignore file.

Executing this is very simple. You just need to do the following actions.

  1. Create .gitignore file right under the project main directory (the same level as .git directory)
  2. In the .gitignore file, list up files or directories you want to exclude from the Git version control system, and save the .gitignore file

To understand the concept more clearly, please go through the practice section below.

 

1. Prepare a test file

Create .env file and run the $ git status command. The $ git status command gives you the status of the files which are recognized by the Git system.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ touch .env
$ git status

You can see that the .env file is recognized by the Git system like below. The response says "untracked" but these files are already recognized by the Git version control system. The status is telling that those files are not added to the Staging Area, which will be explained in more detail later.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

On branch master
No commits yet
Untracked files:
  (use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)
	.DS_Store
	.env
	git_practice.html
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)

 

2. Create and edit the .gitignore file

Create the .gitignore file and launch a text editor. The first command is used to create .gitignore file. The $ code . command is used to launch Visual Studio Code from the terminal. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ touch .gitignore
$ code .

Edit the .gitignore file like below (simply add the 2 lines: .env and .DS_Store.) 

 Text Editor

.env
.DS_Store

Make sure that you save the file.

 

3. Check that the selected files are ignored 

Run the $ git status command to check the files recognized by the Git system

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git status

You can see that the .env file and .DS_Store file are no longer recognized by the Git system as shown below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

On branch master
No commits yet
Untracked files:
  (use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)
	.gitignore
	git_practice.html
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)

Delete the .env file as it will not be used in the following sections.

(As the .DS_Store file is an auto generated file, you don’t need to delete it. Even if you delete it, it will be automatically generated again.)

 

TIPS

There are some useful writing rules.

If you want to exclude all the files with specific extension, you can put * right before the extension like *exe. 

If you want to exclude all the files under one directory, you can put / right after the directory name like bin/.

fields.title: Set UP Remote Repository¬†‚Äî Create Repository And Grant Access
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed

When you want to store and share your project files on GitHub, you need to create a new Remote Repository on GitHub. You also need to grant access to the Remote Repository if you want to work with collaborators for the project. Creating a Remote Repository and granting access is done through the GitHub website. We'll explain detail steps with screenshots of the GitHub website in the Case 1 case study later. The following is a simple explanation of key action items.

1. Create Remote Repository

  • Go to the GitHub website and sign-in to the account.
  • On the main page, you can click right top + mark and select “New repository” or press the green New button on the left.
  • On the “Create a new repository” page, you need to add a repository name, select public or private, and press the Create repository button.

2. Grant Access to Repository

  • Go to the Settings page and select Manage access. Press the Add people button.
  • You can type the GitHub account or email address of the person who you want to collaborate with. If you input the GitHub account, the website will look up the existing GitHub accounts. 
  • When you find the right account, click the green button. The account owner will receive an invitation and they can decide either to accept the invitation or to decline the invitation.

fields.title: Link Remote Repository With Local Repository ‚Äî Git Remote Add
fields.content:
To upload your code from your Local Repository to your Remote Repository, first, you need to create a link between your Local Repository and a Remote Repository. $ git remote add is the command used to establish the link.

For the URL, you can choose HTTPS or SSH depending on which protocol you want to use. You can find the URL of a Remote Repository on the "< > Code" page. Click the green Code button to see URLs like the ones below.

The URL structures are like the examples below. The initial parts of URLs are different. However, the latter parts are the same: GitHub Account Name and Remote Repository Name. origin is typically used for the Remote Repository name.

  • HTTPS: https://github.com/GitHub Account Name/Remote Repository Name.git
  • SSH: git@github.com:GitHub Account Name/Remote Repository Name.git

You can check the Remote Repository URL setting status by running the $ git remote -v.

There are other $ git remote commands, which will be explained in Chapter 7 Remote Collaboration.

fields.title: Upload Local Repository To Remote Repository ‚Äî Git Push
fields.content:
English To Be Reviewed Again

To share your project files through Git Remote Repositories, you need to upload your project directory. Push is an action used to upload your project directory or code from your Local Repository to a Remote Repository. $ git push is the command for pushing codes. When you run the command, you need to specify a Remote Repository name and a branch name which you want to upload.

For a simple Git operation, you should memorize the $ git push origin master command. origin is a typical name for a remote repository. master is the default branch name. Unless you created another branch, master is the only branch.

More details about the push command will be provided in Chapter 7.

fields.title: How To Work With Remote Repository When Launching Project
fields.content:
1st paragraph English To Be Reviewed Again

From this page onwards, we’ll explain how to work with a Remote Repository in a project launch context. The focuses of this page onwards are Case 2 and Case 3 for the project launch actions, however, we'll also cover the latter part of Case 1 to give a more comprehensive views on how the project files are shared with some case examples.

Different stating points

As explained in the beginning of this chapter, when you launch a new Git project, the starting point can be different depending on your situation. 

Here, we’ll illustrate this with three types of developers.

Developer A: The original initiator of the project

Developer B: A team member (collaborator) supporting Developer A on the project

Developer C: An independent developer who wants to leverage existing codes to launch a new project 

The following explanation assumes that all developers already have a GitHub account and a Local Repository is already initiated for this project.

Key Processes for Developer A: 

    Create own repository and share it with others (Case 1)

The objective of Developer A is to start to collaborate with Developer B for the project. He needs to upload his code to his Remote Repository and share it with Developer B.

Here are some Developer A's scenarios.

1. Developer A already has some lines of code to initiate the project, which are already committed in the Local Repository

2. First, Developer A creates a Remote Repository under his GitHub account.

3. To upload his codes in the Local Repository, he needs to establish a link between the Local Repository and the Remote Repository by running the $ git remote add command.

4. Once the Remote Repository and the Local Repository are linked, he can upload his code by running the $ git push command.

5. Finally, he needs to allow Developer B to access his Remote Repository. The operation is made on the GitHub website.

 

Key Processes for Developer B:

    Get access to others’ Remote Repository as a collaborator (Case 2)

The objective of Developer B is to get access to Developer A’s Remote Repository for the project and bring the project directory to her local computer to start the project.

1. When Developer A gives Developer B permission to access to his Remote Repository, an email is sent by GitHub. What Developer B needs to do first is to accept accessing the Remote Repository.

2. Next, she needs to link the Remote Repository with her Local Repository and bring the project directory to her local computer by running the $ git clone command. After cloning the repository, she is ready to collaborate with Developer A.

 

Key Processes for Developer C

    Create a replica of a Remote Repository and bring it to local computer (Case 3)

The objective of Developer C is to launch a project based on Developer A’s existing work. Here we assume that Developer A’s Remote Repository is a public repository. 

1. The first thing Developer C needs to do is to Fork the Repository. Fork creates a replica of an existing repository, however, it is no longer linked with the original repository. Fork operation is done though the GitHub website GUI (Graphic User Interface). Once he created a new Remote Repository by Fork, the new repository is owned by him and he can freely edit the code in his repository

2. To edit the code, he needs to bring the project directory to his local computer by running the $ git clone command

 

Practice Setting

In this section, we’ll use three GitHub accounts to make each role clear. Until the previous section, we were using the bloovee account as the default user. Please pay attention to the usernames and icons to fully understand each context.

fields.title: Case 1. Create Own Repository And Share It With Others
fields.content:
On this page, we'll explain Case 1. In Case 1, you are the owner of the Remote Repository. As the owner, you need to create a Remote Repository yourself and upload your code. You can also give access to the repository to your team members.

There are four key steps for Case 1.

  1. Create a Remote Repository under your GitHub account as the owner.
  2. Establish a link between the Local Repository and the Remote Repository by running the $ git remote add command.
  3. Upload your project directory by running the $ git push command.
  4. Give permission to access the Remote Repository to your team members (collaborators).

After you complete these four actions, collaborators will receive an invitation to access your repository, and they will be ready to transfer the code saved in the Remote repository to their Local Repository. The collaborator's actions will be explained in Case 2 later.

 

On the previous pages, we already created a Local Repository and an html file to be managed by Git. The .gitignore file is also saved in the project main directory (git_practice).

Before going through the four steps, let's check the current project directory structure. If you have the $ tree command installed onto your computer, you can run $ tree -a -L 1 to check your current directory tree. If the $ tree command is not installed yet, you can simply check the directory by viewing hidden files (Press Shift + Command + Period "." to show hidden files for Mac).

 Command Line - INPUT

$ tree -a -L 1

 Command Line - RESPONSE

.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .DS_Store
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .env
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .git
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .gitignore
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ git_practice.html

In this practice, we’ll go through how Developer A can share his project directory with Developer B (sky-blue2022) via a GitHub Remote Repository.

1. Create a Remote Repository under your GitHub account

Go to the GitHub website and sign-in to the account. On the main page, you can click right top + mark and select “New repository” or press the green New button on the left.

On the “Create a new repository” page, you need to add a repository name, select public or private, and press the Create repository button. In this demo, we’ll use the same name as the project. There are some options to create additional documents. You can skip them for this practice.

Once you successfully made the new Remote Repository, you can see the page like the one below. Copy the URL for the next action. You can choose HTTPS or SSH depending on which security protocol you want to use.

 

2. Establish a link between the Local Repository and the Remote Repository

Run the following $ git remote command to establish a link between the Local Repository and the Remote Repository. origin is a standard name for the Remote Repository. (When you clone a Remote Repository, the default name of the Remote Repository on your local computer is also origin.) For the URL, you can use the URL from your Remote Repository.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git remote add origin https://github.com/bloovee/git_practice.git (for HTTPS)

Or

$ git remote add origin git@github.com:bloovee/git_practice.git (for SSH)

After running the $ git remote add command, there is no command line response. To confirm what you have done, you need to check the Remote Repository URL status by running $ git remote -v.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git remote -v

For HTTPS case, you'll see the following response.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

origin  https://github.com/bloovee/git_practice.git (fetch)
origin  https://github.com/bloovee/git_practice.git (push)

 

3. Upload the codes from the Local Repository to the Remote Repository

Run the following command to upload the code from the Local Repository to the Remote Repository. The command line response will be different for HTTPS and SSH. 

In the HTTPS case, the command line will ask for a username and password to the GitHub account. This password that is asked for is actually not the password of the GitHub account. You need to input the PAT (Personal Acccess Token) generated before. 

In the SSH case, the command line will ask for your SSH passphrase. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git push origin master

 Command Line - INTERACTIVE - HTTPS case

Username for 'https://github.com': bloovee
Password for 'https://bloovee@github.com': ‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†PAT‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†
Enumerating objects: 4, done.
Counting objects: 100% (4/4), done.
Delta compression using up to 8 threads
Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
Writing objects: 100% (4/4), 388 bytes | 194.00 KiB/s, done.
Total 4 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
To https://github.com/bloovee/git_practice.git
 * [new branch]      master -> master

 Command Line - INTERACTIVE - SSH case

Enter passphrase for key '/Users/bloovee/.ssh/id_rsa': ‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†Passphrase‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†‚ñ†
Enumerating objects: 4, done.
Counting objects: 100% (4/4), done.
Delta compression using up to 8 threads
Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
Writing objects: 100% (4/4), 388 bytes | 388.00 KiB/s, done.
Total 4 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0), pack-reused 0
To github.com:bloovee/git_practice.git
 * [new branch]      master -> master

 

4. Allow Developer B to access to her Remote Repository

Managing GitHub Repository will be done on the GitHub website. Go to the Settings page and select Manage access. Press the Add people button.

You can type the GitHub account or email address of the person who you want to collaborate with. If you input the GitHub account, the website will look up the existing GitHub accounts as shown below. 

When you find the right account, click the green button. The account owner will receive an invitation and they can decide either to accept the invitation or to decline the invitation. Go to the Case 2 page to see the Developer B side of operations.

fields.title: Case 2. Get Access To Others‚Äô Remote Repository As Collaborator
fields.content:
English (red part) To Be Reviewed

On this page, we'll explain Case 2. In Case 2, you are a team member of a coding project. To start the project, you need to get access to another developer's Remote Repository and bring the project files onto your computer. 

There are two key steps for Case 2. 

  1. Obtain the Remote Repository access from the owner of the Remote Repository First, the owner of the Remote Repository needs to invite you to collaborate in the Remote Repository. The invitation will be sent to your email. By accepting the inivitaion, you'll get access to the Remote Repository.
  2. Create a copy of the project files in the Remote Repository on your local computer. When your team gives you access to the Remote Repository, you can bring the project directories and files in the Remote Repository to your local computer by running the $ git clone command.

 

1. Accept the Remote Repository access invitation

When your team gives access to the Remote Repository, you can bring the files and directories in the Remote Repository to the Local Repository and your working directory on your computer by running the $ git clone command.

In Case 1, Developer A has already sent an invitation to Developer B for his Remote Repository. In this practice, we'll explain from the Developer B's point of view.

After the invitation is sent out, Developer B gets an email like the one below. 

Click the View invitatioon button to see the invitation, and accept the invitation by pressing the Accept invitation button. 

 

2. Run the $ git clone command

Move the directory to create a new project and run the $ git clone [ Remote Repository URL ] command to copy the project files in the Remote Repository onto your local computer.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git clone https://github.com/bloovee/git_practice.git (for HTTPS)

Or

$ git clone git@github.com:bloovee/git_practice.git (for SSH)

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Cloning into 'git_practice'...
remote: Enumerating objects: 4, done.
remote: Counting objects: 100% (4/4), done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
remote: Total 4 (delta 0), reused 4 (delta 0), pack-reused 0
Receiving objects: 100% (4/4), done.

After this, you can see that the git_practice directory is generated under the current directory.

fields.title: Git Clone
fields.content:
The $ git clone command is used to create a link with a Remote Repository and bring the project directory from the remote repository with commit histories to your local computer.

This command is used only the first time you bring the project directory to your local computer. The $ git clone command establishes a connection between the Remote Repository and your local computer by registering the URL to define the location of the Remote Repository onto your computer. Once the connection is established, you can Pull or Fetch the Remote Repository.

Pull and Fetch will be explained in Chapter 7.

When you run the clone command, you need to designate the URL of the Remote Repository which you want to clone. The URLs for HTTPS and SSH are different. As we saw in Chapter 2, you can choose one of them. You can find the URL of the Remote Repository on the "< > Code" page on GitHub. You can see the URLs after clicking the green Code button like shown below.

When you clone a Remote Repository, the default name of the Remote Repository on your local computer is origin. You’ll use the name "origin" quite often in the Git operation. After you clone a Remote Repository, you can check the Remote Repository name and URL on your computer by running $ git remote -v.

fields.title: Case 3. Create Replica Of Remote Repository And Bring It To Local Computer
fields.content:
On this page, we'll explain Case 3. As GitHub is an open platform, you can access many repositories created by someone else. You may want to leverage an existing repository to start your new coding project. 

In Case 3, you'll create a replica of an existing Remote Repository (but it will be an independent project from the original one). This case is also a quite common approach when you learn from an existing project on GitHub public repositories.

There are two key steps for Case 3.

  1. Create a replica of an existing Remote Repository. Find a repository which you want to start a project on top of. On the Remote Repository page on GitHub, find the Fork button to create a replica and bring it to your GitHub account page. 
  2. Clone the Remote Repository. To start a project, you need to bring the project directories and files under the Remote Repository onto your computer by running the $ git clone command. 

 

1. Create a replica of an existing Remote Repository - Fork

Login to your GitHub account. Here we'll explain Developer C's GitHub account: ocean-blue2022. In the image blow, you can see that Developer C signed in as ocean-blue2022. 

For practice purposes, we changed the git_practice repository owned by Developer A (account name: bloovee) from a private repository to a public repository. In this practice exercise, Developer C will Fork the repository. 

To go to the repository, search the repository using the search box. In this case, Developer C found the bloovee/git_practice public repository. To Fork the repository, press the Fork button on the top right.

Now you can see that the git_practice repository is created under the ocean-blue2022 account as shown below.

 

2. Bring the project file in the Remote Repository to the local computer - Clone

After you Fork the repository on GitHub, the next step is the same as in Case 2. You need to run the $ git clone command to bring the project directory onto your computer.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git clone https://github.com/bloovee/git_practice.git (for HTTPS)

Or

$ git clone git@github.com:bloovee/git_practice.git (for SSH)

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Cloning into 'git_practice'...
remote: Enumerating objects: 4, done.
remote: Counting objects: 100% (4/4), done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
remote: Total 4 (delta 0), reused 4 (delta 0), pack-reused 0
Receiving objects: 100% (4/4), done.

After this, the git_practice directory will be generated under the directory in which you run the command. 

The final status seems the same as in Case 2. However, there is a significant difference between Case 2 and Case 3. In Case 2, you are still collaborating with the owner of the original Remote Repository. In Case 3, you completely separate the Remote Repository. The forked repository no longer belongs to the original owner of the repository.

fields.title: Fork vs. Clone
fields.content:
Fork and Clone are often confused with each other. Here we’ll give a quick summary of those two concepts.

Fork is a feature provided by GitHub used to create a replica of a Remote Repository on GitHub. After implementing Fork, the replicated repository will be separated from the original repository. You can modify codes in the replicated repository on your own without permission from the owners of the original repository (within the software license agreement, if any). Fork is not a git command. It is executed on the GitHub website. Go to the GitHub site and find the repository which you want to create a replica of. There is a Fork button on the Remote Repository page. Press the Fork button to implement Fork.

Clone is used to make a link with a Remote Repository and bring the project directory from the Remote Repository to your local computer for the first time.  To implement Clone, you need to run “$ git clone” with the Remote Repository name and the URL of the Remote Repository.

fields.title: Chapter 5. Edit & Commit
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll explain key Git commands used in the cycle of editing and recording code (creating version histories). The following topics are covered in this chapter.

TOPICS

  1. Git Regular Workflow — Edit & Commit
  2. Edit and Commit Codes Overveiw (1)
  3. Edit and Commit Codes Overveiw (2)
  4. Add Files To Staging Area — Git Add
  5. Check Status Of Working Tree And Staging Area — Git Status
  6. Commit Files — Git Commit
  7. Check Commit Histories — Git Log
  8. Check Differences — Git Diff
  9. Restore Files To Working Tree — Git Restore
  10. Delete Files — Git Rm
  11. Undo Changes — Git Reset

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: Git Regular Workflow ‚Äî Edit & Commit
fields.content:
The goal of this section is to master the basic cycle of editing and recording code (creating version histories) with key Git commands.

There are 8 key Git commands you will learn in this section.

  • $ git add: with this command, you can add files to the Staging Area (INDEX), where you can prepare and check files to register in your Local Repository. 
  • $ git status: with this command, you can see the status of the Working Tree (working directory) and the Staging Area (INDEX). This status lets you see which changes have been staged, which haven't, and which files aren't being tracked by Git. 
  • $ git commit: with this command, you can register files in your Local Repository. Once the files are registered by this command, you can retrieve the saved version of the set of files anytime.
  • $ git log: with this command, you can check the infomation of the commit history of the repository
  • $ git diff: with this command, you can check differences among the Working Tree, Staging Area (INDEX) and commit histories.
  • $ git restore: with this command, you can bring your working tree back to the latest commit or a specific commit. This command is useful when you want to clear your edits and go back to a cleaner version.
  • $ git rm: with this command, you can delete files or directories under the Working Tree and the Staging Area (INDEX). When you want to reflect the deleted status as a formal version, you need to create another commit. 
  • $ git reset: with this command, you can reset the Staging Area (INDEX) or change commit histories with or without changing the contents of your local files.

fields.title: Edit and Commit Overveiw (1)
fields.content:
As already explained in Chapter 1, you’ll manage the following three areas in the Git operation.

Working Tree (or Working Directory) is the area where you can edit code or files.

 

If you haven’t run any git commands, the files are not tracked by the Git system. By running the $ git add command, you can bring the files into the Staging Area. 

Staging Area, also called INDEX, is an area to store changes before committing them (creating a new version of a coding history). This area is often used to review changes before finalizing a new version.

By running the $ git commit command, files under the Stating Area are registered in the Local Repository.

Local Repository is the area for keeping record of coding histories: committed files.

By running the $ git log command, you can see the histories of your code.

 

A typical cycle of editing and managing commits

  1. Edit the code in your project Working Tree (e.g., adding a new feature in a program)
  2. Once the code is updated, bring the files to the Staging Area by the $ git add command
  3. If you want to make a snapshot of the project files, commit the files and save the version in the Local Repository by the $ git commit command
  4. Check the status of the Working Tree and the Staging Area by running the $ git status command. If the commit is successfully done, you’ll see a message saying “nothing to commit”
  5. Then, you can start further edits to add another feature in the Workng Tree. In the Git operation, you repeat this cycle.
  6. If you see errors in the files already in the Staging Area, you can clear the files in the Staging Area by running the $ git reset command.
  7. If you want to reverse your recent edits in the Working Tree and bring the latest saved version (latest commit) back to the Working Tree, you can run the $ git restore command.
  8. When you want to delete files or directories from the Working Tree or Staging Area, you can run the $ git rm command. After running the $ git rm command, you need to run the $ git commit command to reflect the deleted status in the commit histories.
  9. $ git reset is also useful when you want to change version histories. By designating a specific commit name when you run the command, you can erase all the commit histories after the designated commit.

fields.title: Edit and Commit Overveiw (2)
fields.content:
We also want to introduce another diagram to explain the same concept as the one on the previous page. This illustration will help understand how Git works with branches, which will the focus of Chapter 6. The following is the explanation of key icons.

  Working Tree or Working Directory, which you see on your local computer for daily editing.

  Staging Area or INDEX. If the Working Tree is inside this dotted circle, the edit status of the Working Tree and the Staging Area are the same.

  Commit. If the Working Tree is inside this bold circle, the edit status of the Working Tree and the commit are the same.

 

In this diagram, you can see the progress of coding horizontally. If icons are on the same status column (e.g., Status B), the files or directories are the same. 

We'll explain the flow step by step in the diagram.

  1. First, the Working Tree and the latest Commit are under the same status (Status B in the diagram).
  2. When you edit files under the Working Tree, the Working Tree status changes from Status B to Status C.
  3. By running the $ git add command, the Working Tree status (e.g., edited files) is reflected in the Staging Area. At this point, both the Working Tree and the Staging Area are in Status C.
  4. If your edited code has an error and you want to reverse it (clear it from the Staging Area), you can run the $ git reset command.
  5. If you want to make a record of the version of the staged files, you can run the $ git commit command.
  6. After the commit action, you can continue to edit and move the Working Tree forward to Status D.
  7. However, you may find an error in the committed files. If that is the case, you can restore the files from the latest commit by running the $ git restore command (the Working Tree is back to Status C).
  8. If you find another error in a committed file, you can also reverse the committed history by running the $ git reset command. For this purpose, you need to designate a commit name to specify to which commit you want to go back.

fields.title: HEAD
fields.content:
When you are working with Git, you'll see the terms HEAD and INDEX frequently. As explained, INDEX is another term for Staging Area.

Local Repository is the place to store all version histories. Version histories are stored as commits. The latest commit (the latest version) is called HEAD. 

The concept of Head is important to understand Git operation. The concept is also useful to understand branch workflow.

To indicate one commit before HEAD, you can use HEAD~ (tilde) or HEAD^ (Caret) . The meaning of ~ and ^ will be different in a multi-branch context. It will be explained in Chapter 6.

fields.title: Add Files To Staging Area ‚Äî Git Add
fields.content:
$ git add is the command used when you want to add files to the Staging Area, where you can prepare and check files to register in your Local Repository.

When running the command, you need to indicate which files or directories to add to the Staging Area. 

When you want to stage a specific file or directory, you can write the file path or directory path like below.

$ git add [directory or file path]

 

Add all files under the current directory

When you want to stage all the files and directories under your current directory, you can use period "." like below.

$ git add .

 

Add all changes under the Working Tree

 When you want to stage only the files changed from the latest commit (HEAD), you can use the "-A" option like below.

$ git add -A

fields.title: Check Status Of Working Tree And Staging Area ‚Äî Git Status
fields.content:
$ git status is the command when you want to see the status of the Working Tree and the Staging Area. This status lets you see which changes have been staged, which haven't, and which files aren't being tracked by Git. 

There are two types of information which the $ git status command provides

Information provided by $ git status
