1. Branch status: which branch you are located in (the branch concept will be explained in the next chapter)

2. Commit status mainly covers the following status

  • Existence of untracked files (

    1

    )
  • Files in the Staging Area but not commited yet (

    2

    )
  • All files are tracked and committed (

    3

    )

 

The following gives some more detail examples of a typical $ git status response.

1

Existence of untracked files. When you haven't run commit before and haven't staged any files, you'll see a message like below. In this case, two untracked files exist in the Git system.

 

On branch master
No commits yet
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        .gitignore
        git_practice.html

 

2

Files in the Staging Area but not commited yet. If you staged some files but not commited them yet, you'll see a message like below. This example shows the status after you added the two untracked files into the Staging Area by running the $ git add command.

 

On branch master
No commits yet
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   .gitignore
        new file:   git_practice.html

 

3

All files are tracked and committed. If you already commited all the files, you'll see the message like below.

 

On branch master
nothing to commit, working tree clean

 

Different files with different status

The status can differ by file. If there are three files like in the illustration (File 1, 2 and 3), you'll see a message like below.

On branch master
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   File_2

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        File_3

In this case, File_1 is already committed and it is not shown in the message. File_2 is already added in the Staging Area but not committed. File_3 is already created in the Working Tree but it is not added to the Staging Area.

fields.title: Commit Files ‚Äî Git Commit
fields.content:
$ git commit is the command when you want to register files in your Local Repository. Once the files are registered with the $ git commit command, you can retrieve the saved version of the set of files anytime.

When you commit files, you need to write some messages about the commit. The messages are recorded along with the code. Typically, you describe what is the changes are about.

There are some frequently used short-cut options for this command.

1. "-m" option: directly add a commit message with the command

The "-m" option is used to describe a commit message directly in the command. If you don't use this option, a registered text editor is launched automatically. In that case, you need to write a commit message on the text editor, save it and close the text editor. The "-m" option is useful to shorten the operation.

2. "-a" option: directly make a commit (skip the Staging Area)

Another option frequently used is the "-a" or "--all" option. To commit a modifiled or deleted file, you need to add the status to the Staging Area by running the $ git add command. The "-a" or "--all" option enables you to skip the process. This option is not applicable for untracked files. For example, when you create a new file from the last commit, the file needs to be added to the Staging Area by running the $ git add command. 

 

You can use these two options together. For example, if you modified some files for fixing a bug and you want to commit the status, you can run the following command.

$ git commit -a -m "Fixed Bugs"

Or

$ git commit -am "Fixed Bugs"

 

Another note for the $ git commit command is that you don't need to designate a file or directory path different from the $ git add command. The Git system already tracks the files in the Working Tree and Staging Area, the $ git commit command automatically detects what files need to be committed.

fields.title: Check Commit Histories ‚Äî Git Log
fields.content:
$ git log is the command used when you want to get the commit history information of the repository.

For example, when you run this command after the first commit, you'll see a message like the one below.

commit f0b40317a525defbe09bd14de23d9f85e1827e01 (HEAD -> master)
Author: bloovee <bloovee@example.com>
Date:   Sat Dec 18 16:16:04 2021 +0800

    The first commit

The first line is Commit Hash. Commit Hash is a unique ID of each commit. When you want to retrieve a commit, you need this hash.

The second line is the ername and email address of the author of the commit.

The third line is the data and time of the commit.

The last line is the message described when the commit is made. 

The Git system tracks histories of commits. For example, if you make another commit with a message of "Modified", the new commit is recorded like below. You can still see the record of "The first commit" after the record of "Modified".

commit 5ef9182e83895ed3c25ded5e89d1bb7e957a1e2f (HEAD -> master)
Author: bloovee <bloovee2021@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Dec 18 16:41:07 2021 +0800

    Modified

commit a2613ec4fb8a280f79f6b59331172052f9911bac
Author: bloovee <bloovee2021@gmail.com>
Date:   Sat Dec 18 16:39:26 2021 +0800

    The first commit

 

Key options of the $ git log command

"--oneline" option: display each commit in oneline

When commit histories become long, you may want to skip some items to display. The "--oneline" option is useful to shorten the descriptions. With this option, each commit history is shown with one line.

5ef9182 (HEAD -> master) Modified
a2613ec The first commit

 

"--graph" option: display commits with a graph

With the "--graph" option, you can see the branch diversion or integration history visually. It is effective when commit histories are more complicated with multiple branches. The branch concept will be explained in Chapter 6. The following is an example of running $ git log with the "--graph" and "--oneline" option. 

*   b5105dc Merged branch A
|\  
| *   8fef9f1 (Branch_A) Merged branch B
| |\  
| | * 3ab0477 (Branch_B) Edit 5 on branch B
| |/  
| * e83087e Edit 4 on branch A
| * 8fcc58c Edit 3 on branch A
* | a815b57 Edit 2 on master branch
* | 931aef2 Edit 1 on master branch
|/  
* 5c1fd7a First Commit

 

TIPS

  1. When you run the $ git log command, the command line switches to a different display mode in which you cannot type.
  2. To go back to the original mode, you need to press the "q" key. "q" means quit.

fields.title: Check Differences ‚Äî Git Diff
fields.content:
$ git diff is the command used when you want to get differences among the Working Tree, the Staging Area (INDEX) and commit histories.

There are four types of differences you can get with the command.

  1. Difference between the Working Tree and INDEX; when you simply run $ git diff, you'll see this difference.
  2. Difference between the Working Tree and one of commit histories; to see this difference, you need to indicate a Commit Hash after $ git diff.
  3. Difference between INDEX and HEAD (the latest commit); the "--cached" option enables you to see the difference between INDEX and one of commit histories. When you don't designate a specific commit, the command gives you the difference between INDEX and HEAD (the latest commit)
  4. Difference between INDEX and one of commit histories; when you see this difference, you need to designate a Comit Hash after the "--cached" option.

 

To help you understand this more clearly, we'll provide more examples.

1.File and Commit History Preparation

In this practice, we'll use the same practice file that was used before: git_practice.html. The initial file contents is shown below.

 Text Editor

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
 <style>
 h1 {
  color:blue;
  font-size:80px
 }
 </style>
</head>
<body>
 <h1>Hello World!</h1>
</body>

First, confirm that the color part is  blue  which we'll change later. Then, commit this file by running the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -a -m "The first commit"

Next, change the color part of the file to  green  like shown below. Keep the rest of code the same and save the file.

 Text Editor

h1 {
  color:green;
  font-size:80px
 }

Then, run the next commit with the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -a -m "Modified commit"

Further change the color part to  yellow . After the file is saved, stage the file by running the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git add -A

Lastly, change the color part to  red  and save the file.

To check the commit status and Commit Hash, run the $ git log command with the "--oneline" option like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

The command line returns the following commit log with a short version of Commit Hash.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

d29bfa5 (HEAD -> master) Modified commit
962ec56 The first commit

 

By now, the status of your git_practice.html file's commits, INDEX and Working Tree becomes the following.

 

2. Check for differences

Using the information above, let's confirm the differences with several combinations.

1. Difference between Working Tree and Staging Area

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff

 Command Line - RESPONSE

diff --git a/git_practice.html b/git_practice.html
index 6f83671..2f90dec 100644
--- a/git_practice.html
+++ b/git_practice.html
@@ -3,7 +3,7 @@
 <head>
  <style>
  h1 {
-  color:yellow;
+  color:red;
   font-size:80px
  }
  </style>

You can see a record showing that the color part is changed from  yellow  to  red .

 

2. Difference between Working Tree and HEAD.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff Head

Or

$ git diff ‚Äãd29bfa5

Note: d29bfa5 is the Commit Hash of the HEAD.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:green;
+  color:red;

You can see a record showing that color part has changed from  green  to  red .

 

3. Difference between Staging Area and Head

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff --cached

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:green;
+  color:yellow;

You can see a record showing that the color part has changed from  green  to  yellow .

 

4. Difference between Staging Area and The first commit

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff --cached 962ec56

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:blue;
+  color:yellow;

You can see a record showing that the color part has changed from  blue  to  yellow .

 

Note:

The $ git diff command can be used for checking differences between branches. If you want to see the differences between Branch_1 and Branch_2, run the following command. 

git diff [Branch_1]..[Branch_2]

The differences are shown after + or -. + means that the lines of code were added in Branch_2 from the point of view of Branch_1. - means that the lines of code were deleted in Branch_2 from the point of view of Branch_1.

+ code added
- code deleted

Branch operations will be explained in more detail in Chapter 6.

fields.title: Restore Committed Files To Working Tree ‚Äî Git Restore
fields.content:
$ git restore is the command when you want to bring your Working Tree back to the latest commit or a specific commit. This command is useful when you want to clear your edits and go back to a cleaner version. There are typically two approaches when you use this command. One is without option and another is with "-s" option.  By using the "-s" option, you can designate a commit which you want to retrieve.

1. No option

When running the following command, you'll see two different results depending on the status of the Stating Area.

$ git restore [ file path or directory path ]
  • When there is any staged file: the Working Tree goes back to the same status as the Staging Area
  • When there is no staged file: the Working Tree goes back to the same status as the latest commit (HEAD)

Note:

$ git checkout [directory or file path] also gives the same results as this command.

 

2. "-s" option: restore files or directories from a specific commit

You can restore files or directories from a specific commit by running the following command.

$ git restore [file path or directory path] -s [Commit Hash]

 You can designate Head instead of a Commit Hash if you want to go back to the latest commit version.

 

TIPS

If you use "." as a directory path, all the files and directories under the current directory will be restored.  

 

For better understanding, please read the following practice.

1. File and Commit History Preparation

In this practice, we'll use the same example as the previou page. Please review the practice section of the previou page if you haven't gone through. The practice file named "git_practice.html" has the following commit histories, INDEX and the Working Tree. Commit Hash is an unique number generated for each commit. When you demonstrate, you see different numbers. For your practice, use the Hash generated on your computer.

 

2. Restore files from different versions

There are three types of approaches to restore files. The following diagram illustrates which version of files you can restore.

 

1

Restore a file from INDEX

By running the following command, you can bring the file status back to the status in the Staging Area.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git restore git_practice.html

Check the file. You can see the color part is changed to  yellow  from   red . This means that the file is back to the version under the Staging Area.If you run the $ git diff command, there is no response as the file status between the Staging Area and the Working Tree became the same.

If there is no version of the file in the Staging Area, the $ git restore command bring back to the latest commit (Head). We'll test it later.

 

2

Restore a file from a specific commit

By running the following command, you can bring the file status to the same as "The first commit" status.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git restore git_practice.html -s 962ec56

Check the file. You can see that the color part is changed to  blue  from  yellow . This means that the file is back to "The first commit" version.

 

3

Restore a file from Head

If you want to back to the latest commit, you can designate Head instead of the commit hash like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git restore git_practice.html -s Head

After running the command, you can see that the color changed into  green .

When there is no version of the file in the Staging Area, the $ git restore command without option will also bring your file status to Head. To confirm this, try the following steps.

First, change the color part into  red , which is the default setting of the Working Tree in this practice, and save the file. To clear the file in the Staging Area, run $ git reset command first. Then, run $ git restore command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset
$ git restore git_practice.html

Check the file. You can see that the color part is changed to  green  from  red . We ran the same command in the begining of the practice. At that time, the color was changed to  yellow  which is the same status in the Staging Area. As the file under the Staging Area was unstaged, the color was changed to the latest commit status, which is  green .

fields.title: Delete Files From Staging Area ‚Äî Git Rm
fields.content:
The $ git rm command can delete a file in the Working Tree and register the status in the Staging Area. To reflect it in a commit history, you need to run the $ git commit command afterwards. If you want to delete a directory, you need to use "-r" option before the directory path.  The typical command flow is as follows.

1. To delete a file (No option)

$ git rm [ file path ]
$ git commit

2. To delete a directory (with "-r" option)

$ git rm -r [ directory path ]
$ git commit

 

For better understanding, please read the following practice section.

1.Prepare a file to delete

For this practice purpose, create a copy of git_practice.html file and commit the new file. Run the $ cp command like the one below.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ cp git_practice.html git_practice_copy.html
$ git add .
$ git commit -m "Added a new file"

2.Delete the file

To delete the file run the $ git rm command and check the status with the $ git status command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git rm git_practice_copy.html
$ git status

After running the command above, you can see the following response

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged ..." to unstage)
        deleted:    git_practice_copy.html

To register the status to the Local Repository, run the $ git commit command. And check the latest commit log.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -m "Deleted the new file"
$ git log --oneline

You can confirm that the deleted status is already registered in the commit histories like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

6d93471 (HEAD -> master) Deleted the new file
ec837bf Added a new file

fields.title: Unstage Files From Staging Area ‚Äî Git Reset
fields.content:
$ git reset is the command when you want to reset the Staging Area (INDEX) or change commit histories with or without changing the files in the Working Tree.

There are mainly two types of usage of this command.

1. No option: clear files in the Staging Area

To clear files in the Staging Area, you need to simply run the $ git reset command like the one below. For this purpose, no need to use option and Commit Hash.

$ git reset

 

2. With Commit Hash and option (soft, mixed, hard): change commit histories 

To change commit histories, you need to specify which commit you want to move back with Commit Hash. By this command, the commits made after the Commit Hash will be erased. As the command can create a significant change, you need to carefully run the command. When changing commit histories, there are three options depending on how you want to change the status of the Staging Area and the Working Tree.

  • --soft: with this option, INDEX and the Working Tree stay unchanged. Only commit histories are reversed.
  • --mixed (default option): with this option, only the status of INDEX will be back to the same status as the commit you designated for this command. The Working Tree stays the same. As --mixed is the default option, if you don't add an option when running the command, the command will act like with the --mixed option.
  • --hard: with this option, the status of INDEX and the Working Tree will be back to the same status of the commit you designated for this command. You need to be extremely careful to run the command with this option as all the changes made after the designated commit will be erased from the three areas (Working Tree, Staging Area and Commit History).

The followings are the command line examples.

$ git reset --hard [Commit Hash]
$ git reset --mixed [Commit Hash]
$ git reset --soft [Commit Hash]

 

For better understanding, please read the following practice.

1. File and Commit History Preparation

In this practice, we'll use the same example as in the $ git diff practice explained earlier. Please review the practice section of the $ git diff page if you haven't gone through it yet. The practice file named "git_practice.html" has the following commit histories, INDEX and the Working Tree. Commit Hash is an unique number generated for each commit. When you demonstrate, you see different numbers. For your practice use the Commit Hash generated on your computer. 

 

 

You can also compare the statuses with the ones in the illustration. The first commit ( blue ) is Status A. Modified Commit ( green ) is Status B. Staging Area ( yellow )  is Status C. And, Working Tree ( red )  is Status D. The following picture is showing exampleso of initial file and commit settings for this practice.

 

2. $ git reset (clear the Staging Area)

Before runnign the $ git reset command, let's comfirm the current status of the Staging Area by running the $ git diff command. You'll see that the color part of the Working Tree is  red  while the color part of the Staring Area is  yellow . ($ git diff gives the changes from the Staging Area to the Working Tree. + part is for the Working Tree and - part is for the Staging Area.)

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:yellow;
+  color:red;

To clear the files in the Staging Area, you can simply run the $ git reset command.  To check the changed status, run the $ git diff command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset
$ git diff

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:green;
+  color:red;

You can see that the color part in the Staging Area is now  green , which is the same as Head. 

For the next exercise, reverse the Staging Area and the Working Tree to the original setting with the following steps.

  • Update the color part in the Working Tree into  yellow 
  • Run $ git add git_practice.html
  • Update the color part in the Working Tree into  red 

Once you confirm that the status is back to the same as the practice default settings, go to the next exercise.

 

3. $ git reset --soft

$ git reset with the --soft option is used to change only commit histories. In this practice, we'll target to back to The first commit, which Commit Hash is 962ec56. On your computer, you see different one. You need to use the Commit Hash generated on your computer. 

To demonstrate the command and confirm the results, run $ git reset --soft command followed by $ git log. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset --soft 962ec56
$ git log --oneline

In the command line response, you see that Modified commit is disapear and Head becomes The first commit (962ec56) like the one below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

962ec56 (HEAD -> master) The first commit

Also, check the status of the Stagigng Area and the Working Tree by running the $ git diff command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff

You'll see that the Staging Area and the Working Tree remain the same.

  • Staging Area ->  yellow  ( after the - mark)
  • Working Tree ->  red  ( after the + mark)

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:yellow;
+  color:red;

For the next exercise, reverse the commit histories to the original status. When reverse the $ git reset operation, you can use ORIG_HEAD. ORIG_HEAD is the commit before running $ git reset command.

Run the following commands and see the commit histories are reversed.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset ORIG_HEAD
$ git log --oneline

 Command Line - RESPONSE

d29bfa5 Modified commit
962ec56 The first commit

 

4. $ git reset --mixed

The --mixed option is default setting. You can run the command without the option to get the same results. You can try the command both with the option and without the option.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset --mixed 962ec56

Or

$ git reset 962ec56

To check the results, run the $ git log and $ git diff commands.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

 Command Line - RESPONSE

962ec56 (HEAD -> master) The first commit

You can see that Head is now The first commit (962ec56)

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git dff

 Command Line - RESPONSE

-  color:blue;
+  color:red;

You can see that the Staging Area becomes the same as Head while the Working Tree remains the same.

  • Staging Area ->  blue  ( after the - mark). This is the same as Head.
  • Working Tree ->  red  ( after the + mark)

For the next exercise, reverse the commit histories to the original status by running the $ git reset ORIG_HEAD command. Also, you need to reverse the Staging Area status as well with the following steps.

  • Update the color part in the Working Tree into  yellow 
  • Run $ git add git_practice.html
  • Update the color part in the Working Tree into  red 

Once you confirm that the status is back to the same as the practice default settings, go to the next exercise.

 

 5. $ git reset --hard

The --hard option is the strongest option. The command will clear the current Working Tree and Staging Area status, and make them the same as the target commit status. As your efforts can be completely erased by this command, you need to be very careful when you are running the command with this option.

By running the following commands, you can see the same results as the case of the other options.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset --hard 962ec56
$ git log --oneline

 Command Line - RESPONSE

962ec56 (HEAD -> master) The first commit

To check the status of the Staging Area, run $ git diff or $ git diff --cached command. For both commands, you don't get any reponse as Head, INDEX and the Working Tree become the same status after the $ git reset --hard command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git diff
$ git diff --cached

 Command Line - RESPONSE

There is no reponse.

fields.title: Chapter 6. Work With Branches
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll explain branch and related key Git commands. Topics covered in this chapter are the following.

TOPICS

  1. Git Regular Workflow — Work With Branches
  2. What Is Branch?
  3. Branch Operation Basic Life Cycle
  4. Create Branch And Check Branch Status — Git Branch
  5. Switch Current Branch (1) — Git Checkout
  6. Switch Current Branch (2) — Git Switch
  7. Merge Branches — Git Merge
  8. Fast Forward Merge
  9. Non Fast Forward Merge (No Option)
  10. Non Fast Forward Merge (--no-ff Option)
  11. Squash Merge
  12. Managing Conflict
  13. Rebase Branch — Git Branch
  14. Stash Changes — Git Stash

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: Git Regular Workflow ‚Äî Work With Branches
fields.content:
The goal of this section is to help you understand how to manage branches, which is one of the most critical concepts of the Git operations. 

In this section, we'll cover six key git commands.

  • $ git branch: this command is a multi-use command. For example, it is used for creating a new branch, checking branch status and deleting an unused branch.
  • $ git checkout: with this command, you can switch your current branch to a selected branch. 
  • $ git switch: with this command, you can get the same result as $ git checkout. It is a newly introduced command as a substitute of the $ git checkout command.
  • $ git merge: with this command, you can merge branches. The merge operation can be done through a Remote Repository on the GitHub website. Merge operation on GitHub will be explained in the next chapter.
  • $ git rebase: with this command, you can reapply commits on top of another base branch. This command is useful when you want to streamline the commits diverged into multiple branches. The rebase operation can also be done through a Remote Repository on the GitHub website. It is an option of the merge-feature of GitHub.
  • $ git stash: with this command, you can separately manage WIP (Work In Progress) codes. When you want to switch the current branch in the middle of editing the Working Tree, the edits can prevent from switching the current branch. In that case, this command is useful. The stashed lines of code are parked somewhere temporarily.

fields.title: What Is Branch?
fields.content:
A Branch in Git is an independent line of development with a comit history. Different branches give a different recording space; each branch has its own coding history (a line of commits). 

Branches allow us to manage different versions of the same set of project files simultaneously. For example, one developer can work on adding a new promotion campaign feature while another developer is working on adding a new payment feature to the same web application. 

Git provides a master branch as a default. Unless you create a new branch, all your work is done on the master branch. The branch to create a new feature is typically called a topic branch. 

Once development is completed in a topic branch, you can merge it with the master branch or its parent branch. 

With the branching functionality, you can collaborate with others efficiently. Or even you can utilize branches by yourself to manage versions to develop different features simultaniously.

We already shared above explanation in Chapter 1. Here, we'll show how branches are recorded. The slide shows two illustrations. Both illustrations have codes like M1, M2, etc.. Each of them a representation of one commit. 

  • The upper illustration with the tree structure describes how branches can diverge and integrate along coding work. This tree illustration is commonly used to have an overvew of branches with commit histories.
  • The lower illustration with the boxes describes how branches are stored. A branch is like a file box to store snapshots of coding history files. When a new commit is made, the snapshot of the project files for the commit is stored in the file box. Also, when one branch merges with another branch, the history of commits are also carried.

You can confirm that the branch tree status on the command line by running the $ git log command with the "--oneline" and "--graph" option. The screenshots of the command line displayed below are the examples of the branch logs aligned with the illustrations.

The seven digit code is a Commit Hash (short version) and you can also see the status of each branch. You can compare the commit titles (M1, M2,..) with the illustration. As all branches are merged with the master branch, you can see all the branch status from the master branch. However, for Branch A, B and C, you can see the commit histories which is related to their own histories. 

Example 1: Master Branch's Commit History

You can see the histories of all the branches from the master branch as all the branches are already merged with the master branch.

 

Example 2: Branch A's Commit History

On the other hand, you have a limited view from Branch A. It is because all the changes after commit A2 were made on the other branches.

 

Example 3: Branch B's Commit History

You can see that Branch C was diverged from Branch B at commit B2 and merged with Branch B at commit B3.

 

Example 4: Branch C's Commit History

You can see that Branch C was diverged from Branch B. However, the commit merging Branch C into Branch B is not visible from Branch C's status as the merge operation was done on Branch B. There is no impact on Branch C by the merge operation on Branch B.

fields.title: Branch Operation Basic Life Cycle
fields.content:
On this page, we'll explain a basic life cycle for the branch operation with the seven steps.

Step 1: Create a new branch

As a default setting, you are working on the master branch. Edit and commit operations explained in Chapter 5 were conducted on the master branch.

When you want to diverge your work from the master branch, you need to create a new branch by running the  $ git branch [new branch name] command.

Step 2: Check the branch status

To check your branch status (i.e., the list of branches and the current branch) in the command line, you need to run the $ git branch command. When you designate a branch name as the command parameter, the command creates a new branch. For a checking status purpose, you just simply run the command without any parameter.

Step 3: Switch branches

When you create a new branch by the $ git branch [new branch name] command, you are still on the original branch; if you are creating a new branch in the first time, you are still on the master branch. To move to the new branch, you have to run one of the following commands

  • $ git checkout [branch name]
  • $ git switch [branch name]

Previously, the $ git checkout command is only an option to do this, howerver, $ git switch command was introduced as a substitute of $ git checkout command. Currently, you can use both commands to get the same result.

Step 4: Edit and Commit on branches

We already explained edit and commit operations in Chapter 4. The practice is applied regardless of branches. What you may need to be careful is on which branch you are operating. When you make a commit, the commit is applied to a specific branch which you are operating on. 

Step 5: Integrate branches

There are two ways to integrate branches: Merge and Rebase. 

Merge is to join two or more development histories together. You can merge branches by running $ git merge in your command line. Rebase is to reapply commits on top of another base branch. The command to implement rebase is $ git rebase. 

Both merge and rebase operations can be done on the GitHub platform. On GitHub, rebase is one option of the merge action. The merge operation on GitHub will be explained in the next chapter.

Step 6: Manage conflicts

If there are changes in the same line of code in different branches, the Git system cannot merge those branches automatically. This situation is called conflicts. You need to resolve conflicts before merging the branches. You can manually fix the lines of code to resolve conflicts.

Step 7: Delete an unused branch

A merged branch is not automatically deleted unless you delete it. After several branching and merging operations, you may see many unused branches in your repository. To delete a branch, you can use the $ git branch -d [branch name] command. 

 

In the following pages, you’ll learn how to manage branches in more detail.

fields.title: Create Branch And Check Branch Status ‚Äî Git Branch
fields.content:
$ git branch is a multi-use command. We'll explain the three majour usages on this page.

Three major usage of the $ git branch command

  1. Creating a new branch
  2. Check the branch status
  3. Delete an unused existing branch

 

1. Creating a new branch

Creating a new branch is the first ation in the branch operation. When running $ git branch [new branch name], a new branch is created on the original branch where you are located, however, you are still on the orginal branch until you switch the currnet branch to the newly created branch by running the $ git checkout or $ git switch command, which will be explained in the next page. Also, one important note here is a new branch is diverged from the latest commit (HEAD) of the parent branch. Unless you rebase it (to be explained later), the diverged point remains the same.

 

2. Check the branch status

When you simply run the $ git branch command without any additions, the command line returns the branch status. The branch status include a list of branches and which branch you are located. In the following exmaple, there are two branches: master branch and Branch_A. The branch with " * " is the current branch, which is the master branch in this case. 

 

The $ git branch command with "-a"option returns list of branches including branch information in a Remote Repository recorded in the Local Repository if the Local Repository is already linked with the Remote Repository. Branches in the Remote Repository will be explained in the next chapter.

 

3. Delete an unused branch

When you don't need a branch after merging with another branch, you can delete the branch by running the $ git branch -d [existing branch name] command. If the branch you are trying to delete has not been merged with any other branches, the command line gives you an error. If you want to really delete the branch (for example, when you mistakenly made a new branch), you can use -D option. $ git branch -D [existing branch name] allows you to delete a branch regardless of its merge history.

 

There are other usages of the $ git branch command. For example, if you want to change a branch name, you can use the "-m" option. Switch to the branch you want to rename. Then, run the $ git branch -m [new branch name] command.

fields.title: Switch Current Branch (1) ‚Äî Git Checkout
fields.content:
$ git checkout is used when you want to switch your branch to a selected branch. As explained in the previous page, the $ git branch [new branch name] creates a new branch but the current branch location stays the same.

 

When you use this command with the -b option, you can create a new branch and checkout to the new branch at the same time. 

 

When you checkout to another branch, the Git system try to carry the changes in the Working Tree and INDEX to the distination branch. If the latest commit status of both branches are the same, you can carry the Working Tree and INDEX (see illustration A). However, if one of the branches is already advanced, you cannot checkout to the distination branch (see illustration B). 

 

When you encounter the situation like illustration B, you'll see an error message like below.

 

To avoid the situation like illustration B, you have some options

Option 1. Commit all the changes and make INDEX, Wroking Tree and HEAD the same

Option 2. Stash the changes (refer the $ git stash page)

Option 3. Forcefully checkout by running the $ git checkout command with the -f option

When you use the -f option, you need to be very careful as INDEX and changes in the Working Tree are all cleared.

fields.title: Switch Current Branch (2) ‚Äî Git Switch
fields.content:
$ git switch is a newly introduced command as a substitute of the $ git checkout command. $ git switch returns the same result as $ git checkout although some options are different. For example, the "-b" option for $ git checkout is the "-c" option for $ git switch. The following is the key commands with comparison with the $ git checkout command

Switch the current branch

  • $ git switch [existing branch name]
  • $ git checkout [existing branch name]

Create a new branch and switch to the new branch

  • $ git switch -c [new branch name]
  • $ git checkout -b [new branch name]

Forcefully switch to another branch

  • $ git switch -f [existing branch name]
  • $ git checkout -f [existing branch name]

 

To understand the following three commands (git branch, git checkout, git switch), please go through the practice below.

1. Prepare a practice file

For the practice purpose, create a new directory and a file; prepare a different directory and a file from the previous chapter. We use the following directory and file in this practice.

  • Working directory: git_branch_practice
  • File: git_branch_practice.htlml

Run the following command to create the new directory and file.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ mkdir git_branch_practice
$ cd git_branch_practice
$ touch git_branch_practice.html

Open the git_branch_practice.html file with a text editor and make the following edits. 

 Text Editor

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<body>
<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch A-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch A-->

<!-- Branch B-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch B-->
</body>

For easier understanding, we'll add texts for each branch under different locations. <!-- --> is used for making comments for html file. In the above case, we created three writing areas for each branch: Master Branch, Branch_A and Branch_B. At this stage, an existing branch is only the master branch. For the master branch section, write "M1" udner <h1> tag which will be the same as the commit message which we will create later on.

Next, commit the file with "M1" as a commit message. Run the follwoing command to execute. As we haven't initiated Git in the new working directory, run the $ git init command first. Add the files under the wokring directory to the Stating Area (in this case, only one file) and commit it. To check the commit status, run the $ git log command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git init
$ git add .
$ git commit -m "M1"
$ git log --oneline

You can see that a new commit "M1" is created like the one below

 Command Line - RESPONSE

5a335b9 (HEAD -> master) M1

 

2. Create a new branch

Create Branch_A by running the $ git brach Branch_A command followed by $ git branch to check the branch status.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git branch Branch_A
$ git branch

You can see that a new branch Branch_A has been created already, however, the current branch is still the master branch like the one below. (The branch with asterisk " * " is the current branch)

  Command Line - RESPONSE

  Branch_A
* master

 

3. Switch to the new branch

To make a new edit on the new branch. Switch the current branch to Branch_A by running $ git checkout or $ git switch command. Also, run $ git branch command to confirm that the current branch is switch to Branch_A.

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A Or $ git switch Branch_A
$ git branch

You can see that the current branch is switched to Branch_A like the one below.

   Command Line - RESPONSE

* Branch_A
  master

 

4. Edit and commit on the new branch (Branch_A)

To make another version of the project file, edit the git_branch_practice.html file. In this time, change only the Branch_A section of the file. Change N/A into A1, which will be the same as the first commit message on this branch.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch A-->
<h1>A1</h1>
<!-- /Branch A-->

 After saving the file, commit the file and check the log.

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "A1"
$ git log --oneline

You can see that a new commit is created on Branch_A.

   Command Line - RESPONSE

32445b0 (HEAD -> Branch_A) A1
5a335b9 (master) M1

 

5. Create a new branch and switch to the new branch with shortcut

Go back to the master branch first to create another new branch from the master branch. To create Branch_B and switch to the branch by one command, run $ git checkout -b Branch_B or $ git switch -c Branch_B. And check the branch status.

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git checkout -b Branch_B Or $ git switch -c Branch_B
$ git branch

You can see that Branch_B is created and it became the current branch.

   Command Line - RESPONSE

  Branch_A
* Branch_B
  master

 

6. Edit and commit on the new branch (Branch_B)

 To make another version of the project file, edit the git_branch_practice.html file again. In this time, change only the Branch_B section of the file. Change N/A into B1, which will be the same as the first commit message on this branch.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch B-->
<h1>B1</h1>
<!-- /Branch B-->

 After saving the file, commit the file with a message of "B1" and check the log.

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "B1"
$ git log --oneline

You can see that a new commit is created on Branch_B. Although we have made a commit on Branch_A, we cannot see it in this log. This is because Branch_B is diverged from the master branch (not from Branch_A).

   Command Line - RESPONSE

5f7f150 (HEAD -> Branch_B) B1
5a335b9 (master) M1

 

7. Forcefully switch to another branch

At the latest situation, you can switch to another branch as all changes are already commited (the Working Tree and the Staging Area are the same as HEAD). To create a situation that you cannot switch to another branch like the case explained in the previous page, edit the practice file again and save it like the one below.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch B-->
<h1>B1</h1>
<h1>B2</h1>
<!-- /Branch B-->

 Af this stage, the above edit is only reflected into the Working Tree and it is not commited. Try to switch to Branch_A with the following command.

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A

In this case, you'll encounter the error message like the one below. 

   Command Line - RESPONSE

error: Your local changes to the following files would be overwritten by checkout:
        git_branch_practice.html
Please commit your changes or stash them before you switch branches.
Aborting

 Now try to switch to Branch_A with the "-f" option and check the branch status.

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout -f Branch_A
$ git branch

 This time, you successfully swtiched to Branch_A, however, the changes done in the Working Tree is cleared by this command. You can check the status in your file.

   Command Line - RESPONSE

* Branch_A
  Branch_B
  master

 

8. Delete a branch

Lastly, delete Branch_B. As the branch has not been merged yet, the "-d" option won't work. Use the "-D" option instead. Run the following commands and check the branch status.

   Command Line - INPUT

$ git branch -D Branch_B
$ git branch

You can see that Branch_B is already erased.

   Command Line - RESPONSE

* Branch_A
  master

For the next practice, let's also delete Branch_A by running the following commands.

   Command Line - INPUT

$ git switch master
$ git branch -D Branch_A
$ git branch

You can see that only the master branch exists.

   Command Line - RESPONSE

* master

fields.title: Merge Branches ‚Äî Git Merge
fields.content:
$ git merge is the command used when you want to merge branches. The merge operation can be done through the Remote Repository on the GitHub website; it will be explained further in the next chapter.

When you run the $ git merge command, you need to run the commnd from the branch you want to continue to work on, and designate a target branch name which you want to merge into the current branch.

There are several cases for merge actions depending on the status of branches and command options.

 

1. Fast-Forward Merge

When you are merging a child branch which is simply ahead of the parent branch (no changes in the parent branch after the point when you created the child branch), the $ git merge command simply brings changes made in the child branch into the parent branch without creating a new commit.  In this case, the status of the branches will shift to the one like the following illustration.

By this command, HEAD of the master branch moves forward to the point of HEAD of Branch_A. The merge command doesn't impact the target branch. In this case, there is no change in Branch_A. Simply, the master branch becomes the same as the status of Branch_A. 

 

Key Points of Fast-Forward Merge

  • No commit is created
  • HEAD of Master Branch moves forward to the same commit as HEAD of Branch_A
  • Branch_A still remains the same (it is not deleted by the merge command)
  • Master Branch and Branch_A become the same status

 

2. Non-Fast-Forward Merge

When the parent branch (e.g., master branch) is already ahead of the diverged point of the child branch, the merge action becomes non-fast-forward merge. In this case, the merge action is recorded as a commmit. When you run the $ git merge command, a text editor is launched to add a commit message. Short desctiption is already written in the text editor. You can change the message or just save it. When you close the editor, the merge action is completed. The following illustration describes before and after of the non-fast forward merge. 

In this case, HEAD of the master branch moves forward integrating all commit histories under Branch_A. 

 

Key Points of Non-Fast Forward Merge

  • A commit is created
  • HEAD of Master Branch moves forward with integrating the changes made in Branch_A
  • Branch_A's commit histories are also recorded under Master Branch
  • Branch_A still remain the same (it is not deleted by the merge command)

 

3. Non-Fast Forward Merge with the "--no-ff" option

Even when the status of branches is the same as the fast forward case, you may want to create a commit. If that is the case, you can use the "--no-ff" option. The command enforces to create a commit like the illustration below. The merge result becomes almost the same as the previous case; the only difference is that the previous case has commit M4 before HEAD on the master branch.

 

4. Squash Merge

Squash is another approach when you merge branches. This approach is useful when you don't want to keep an every single detail of change histories in the master branch. When you run $ git merge command with the "--squash" option, all the changes made in the target branch are reflected to the marging branch (destination branch: TBC). However, the command doesn't create a new commit. The changes are only reflected to the Working Tree and INDEX (see the illustration below). When you want to proceed the change, you need to make a new commit by running the $ git commit command. By the command, only one new commit is recorded under the master branch. All commits under Branch_A are combined (squashed) to the new commit.

 

Key Points of Squash Merge

  • No commit is created by the $ git merge command
  • The status of Branch_A (changes made after the diverged point from the master branch: commit A1 and A2) is integrated to the Working Tree and INDEX of the master branch
  • You need to create a new commit to record the merge operation
  • Branch_A's commit histories are not recorded under Master Branch (All commits under Branch_A are combined (squashed) to the new commit)
  • Branch_A still remains the same (it is not deleted by the merge command)

fields.title: Fast-forward Merge
fields.content:
On this page, we'll exaplain about the Fast-forward merge in more detail with command line examples. 

The command line image below is a demonstration of the commit and merge actions, which are the same as the upper illustration on the main slide. M1-3 and A1-2 are commit titles are already made before this demonstration. We'll explan about the commands and response in the command line by four steps.

  1. Confirm the original commit history status by running the $ git log command on Branch_A. You can see that the commit histories and branch status are the same as the illustration on the main slide.
  2. Switch to the master branch and run the $ git merge Branch_A command. You can see that this merge is Fast-forward.
  3. Confirm how the commit history look like on the master branch by running the $ git log command. You can see that the HEAD of master branch is moved forward to the same position as the HEAD of Branch_A
  4. To confirm the status of Branch_A, switch to Branch_A and run the $ git log command. You can see the same result as the one of the master branch. This means that Branch_A and the master branch are in the same status now

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file

In this practice, we start with creating the original file with commit M1-M3 and A1-A2. From the previous practice on the Git Switch page, we already have git_branch_practice.html file under git_branch_practice directory. As we already deleted Branch_A and Branch_B, you should have only the master branch by now. The content of the master branch is like the one below.

 Text Editor

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<body>
<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch_A-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch_A-->

<!-- Branch_B-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch_B-->

</body>

To align with the upper illustration on the main slide, let's make commit M2 and M3 first. For a practice purpose, add <h1>Commit Message (e.g., M1, M2, etc.)</h1> for each commit so that you can see the linkage between the file content and each commit. 

 Add M2 under the html file and save it. Then, make a commit with "M2" as a commit message.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "M2"

Repeat the same actions for commit M3.

Next is to create Branch_A and checkout to the branch.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout -b Branch_A

To create A1 and A2 commit, repeat the same actions as what you have done for commit M2 and M3.

Run the $ git log command to see the commit history.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

You'll see the following status like below. Commit Hash is a uniqe numbers generated by the computer each time. You'll see different ones on your computer, however, the structure of commit histories and branch status will be the same.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c (master) M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

2. Perform the merge commit

As you need to run the merge command from the master branch, first switch the current branch to the master branch. Then, run the merge command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git branch master
$ git merge Branch_A

The command line response shows that Fast-forward merge is conducted.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Updating 33e8f0c..b15e35a
Fast-forward
 git_branch_practice.html | 3 ++-
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 

3. Check commit histories and branch status

Check the status on the master branch first.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

You can see that the HEAD of the master branch moved forward to the same position as the HEAD of Branch_A. Also, you can confirm that no new commit is created by this operation. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> master, Branch_A) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

Next, check the status on Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A
$ git log --oneline

You can see exactly the same results as the one on the master branch. This means that the master branch and Branch_A are in the same status now.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> Branch_A, master) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

fields.title: Non Fast-forward Merge (No Option)
fields.content:
On this page, we'll exaplain about the Non-Fast-forward merge in more detail with command line examples. This page is a continued explanation from the previos page.

The command line image below is a demonstration of the commit and merge actions, which are the same as the upper illustration on the main slide. M1-3 and A1-2 are commit titles are already made before this demonstration. We'll explan about the commands and response in the command line by three steps.

  1. You can confirm that commit M4 is already added from the original status on the previous page and the status is aligned with the upper illustration of the main slide. (Please check the practice section below to see how to build this status.)
  2. Run the $ git merge command. When runnig the command, you'll see a temporary message on the command line saying "hint: Waiting for your editor to close the file ..." and a text editor is launched like the image below. A commit message is already written there. Save and close the editor. In this demo, we are using Visual Studio Code as the registered editor.
  3. Check the branch status by running the $ git log command. You can see that the HEAD of master is ahead of the Head of Branch_A as we created a new commit for the merge operation.

 

Example: commit message on a text editor

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file

In the practice on the previous page, we already made commit M1-3 on the master branch and A1-A2 on Branch_A. Also, merged Branch_A with the master branch. To move back to the original file status, reset the merge operation by running $ git reset --hard command on the master branch to reverse the HEAD of the master branch to commit M3. Use the Commit Hash of commit M3 which is generated on your computer. Also, make sure using the "--hard" option. If you don't use the option, the status of Working Tree, Staging Area and HEAD will be mixed.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git reset --hard 33e8f0c
$ git log --oneline

You'll see that the HEAD of the master branch is back to Commit M3.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

33e8f0c (HEAD -> master) M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

Next, create commit M4 to align with the upper illustration of the main slide. Edit the html file (add <h1>M4</h1> and run the $ git commit command. To check the latest status, run $ git log command again.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<h1>M3</h1>
<h1>M4</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "M4"
$ git log --oneline

Finally, you'll see the following status, which is aligned with the upper illustration of the main slide for the master branch. As we haven't touched Branch_A, its status remains the same.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

a7a6063 (HEAD -> master) M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

2. Perform the merge commit

Now you are ready to execte the merge command. As you are already on the master branch, run the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git merge Branch_A

In the Non-Fast-forward case, the command line becomes an interactive mode while a text editor is launched. The text editor is used to write a commit message. A simple message is already written. Unless you want to add another message, you can close the text editor as it is.

 Command Line - INTERACTIVE

Auto-merging git_branch_practice.html
hint: Waiting for your editor to close the file...

 Text Editor

Merge branch 'Branch_A'
# Please enter a commit message to explain why this merge is necessary,
# especially if it merges an updated upstream into a topic branch.
#
# Lines starting with '#' will be ignored, and an empty message aborts
# the commit.

When you closed the editor, the merge command is completed like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Merge made by the 'ort' strategy.
 git_branch_practice.html | 3 ++-
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 

3. Check commit histories and branch status

Check the status on the master branch first. Add the "--graph" option this time as the branch status is slightly more complicated than the previous example.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline --graph

You can see that the HEAD of the master branch is ahead of the HEAD of Branch_A. Also, you can confirm that a new commit is created by this operation. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

*   f1d4276 (HEAD -> master) Merge branch 'Branch_A'
|\  
| * b15e35a (Branch_A) A2
| * 3c6b00d A1
* | a7a6063 M4
|/  
* 33e8f0c M3
* afdcd4c M2
* 5a335b9 M1

Next, check the status on Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A
$ git log --oneline

You can see that nothing has changed for Branch_A

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

fields.title: Non Fast-forward Merge (--no-ff Option)
fields.content:
On this page, we'll exaplain about the Non-Fast-forward merge with the "--no-ff" option in more detail with command line examples.

The command line image below is a demonstration of the commit and merge actions, which are the same as the upper illustration on the main slide. M1-3 and A1-2 are commit titles are already made before this demonstration. We'll explan about the commands and response in the command line by three steps.

  1. You can confirm that commit M4 is already erased from the original status on the previous page and the status is aligned with the upper illustration of the main slide. (Please check the practice section below to see how to build this status.)
  2. Run the $ git merge command with "--no-ff" option. When runnig the command, you'll see a temporary message on the command line saying "hint: Waiting for your editor to close the file ..." and a text editor is launched like the image below. A commit message is already written there. Save and close the edito. In this demo, we are using Visual Studio Code as the registered editor.
  3. Check the branch status by running the $ git log command. You can see that HEAD of master is ahead of Head of Branch_A as we created a new commit for the merge operation.

 

Example: commit message on a text editor

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file

In the practice on the previous page, we create commit M4 on the master branch and merged Branch_A with the master branch. To move back to the original file status, reset the merge operation by running $ git reset --hard command on the master branch to reverse the HEAD of the master branch to commit M3. Use the Commit Hash of commit M3 which is generated on your computer. Also, make sure using the "--hard" option. If you don't use the option, the status of Working Tree, Staging Area and HEAD will be mixed.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git reset --hard 33e8f0c
$ git log --oneline

You'll see that the HEAD of the master branch is back to Commit M3, which is aligned with the upper illustration of the main slide for the master branch.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

33e8f0c (HEAD -> master) M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

2. Perform the merge commit

Now you are ready to execte the merge command. As you are already on the master branch, run the following command with the "--no-ff" option. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git merge --no-ff Branch_A

As the same as the previous page, the command line becomes an interactive mode while a text editor is launched. The text editor is used to write a commit message. A simple message is already written. Unless you want to add another message, you can close the text editor as it is.

 Command Line - INTERACTIVE

Auto-merging git_branch_practice.html
hint: Waiting for your editor to close the file...

 Text Editor

Merge branch 'Branch_A'
# Please enter a commit message to explain why this merge is necessary,
# especially if it merges an updated upstream into a topic branch.
#
# Lines starting with '#' will be ignored, and an empty message aborts
# the commit.

When you closed the editor, the merge command is completed like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Merge made by the 'ort' strategy.
 git_branch_practice.html | 3 ++-
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 

3. Check commit histories and branch status

Check the status on the master branch first. Add the "--graph" option this time as the branch status is slightly more complicated than the previous example.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline --graph

You can see that the HEAD of the master branch is ahead of the HEAD of Branch_A. Also, you can confirm that a new commit is created by this operation. Only differences from the previous case (the Fast-forward no-optin case) is that there is no M4 commit and Commit Hash for the last commit.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

*   769fab1 (HEAD -> master) Merge branch 'Branch_A'
|\  
| * b15e35a (Branch_A) A2
| * 3c6b00d A1
|/  
* 33e8f0c M3
* afdcd4c M2
* 5a335b9 M1

Next, check the status on Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A
$ git log --oneline

You can see that nothing has changed for Branch_A

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

fields.title: Squash Merge
fields.content:
On this page, we'll exaplain about merge with the "--squash" option in more detail with command line examples.

The command line image below is a demonstration of the commit and merge actions, which are the same as the upper illustration on the main slide. M1-3 and A1-2 are commit titles are already made before this demonstration. We'll explan about the commands and response in the command line by six steps.

  1. You can confirm that commit M4 is already added from the original status on the previous page and the status is aligned with the upper illustration of the main slide. (Please check the practice section below to see how to build this status.)
  2. Run the $ git merge command with "--squash" option. When runnig the command with the option, no commit is created. What happend by the command is to bring changes made on Branch_A to the Working Tree and INDEX. 
  3. To confirm that the changes are not commited yet on the master branch, run $ git status command. You can see a modified file under INDEX. To understand what changes are made in the file, you can see an example in the image below. To simplify the explanation, we are editing the file aligned with each commit name. For example, add A1 under <h1> tag before making a commit of "A1". You can see the file on the master branch is an integrated version of master branch (before squash) and Branch_A. 
  4. To make a record of the change, run the $ git merge command. 
  5. Check the latest branch status, run the $ git log command on the master branch. You can see that a new commit is created, however, there are not A1 and A2 in the commit history. This means that the squash option combined (squashed) all the changes made on the merging branch to simplify the line of commit history.
  6. To check the latest status of Branch_A, switch to Branch_A and run the $ git log command. You can see that nothing's changed on Branch_A

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file

In the practice on the previous page, we merged Branch_A with the master branch. To move back to the original file status, reset the merge operation by running $ git reset --hard command on the master branch to reverse the HEAD of the master branch to commit M3. Use the Commit Hash of commit M3 which is generated on your computer. Also, make sure using the "--hard" option. If you don't use the option, the status of Working Tree, Staging Area and HEAD will be mixed.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git reset --hard 33e8f0c
$ git log --oneline

You'll see that the HEAD of the master branch is back to Commit M3.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

33e8f0c (HEAD -> master) M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

Next, create commit M4 to align with the upper illustration of the main slide. Edit the html file (add <h1>M4</h1> and run the $ git commit command. To check the latest status, run $ git log command again.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<h1>M3</h1>
<h1>M4</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "M4"
$ git log --oneline

Finally, you'll see the following status, which is aligned with the upper illustration of the main slide for the master branch. As we haven't touched Branch_A, its status remains the same.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

0cbd7c0 (HEAD -> master) M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

2. Perform squash merge

Now you are ready to execte the merge command. As you are already on the master branch, run the following command with the "--squash" option. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git merge --squash Branch_A

 In this case, no commit is made as you can see the response in the commandline like below. In stead, changes made on Branch_A are reflected in the Working Tree of the master branch like the one in the text editor below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Auto-merging git_branch_practice.html
Squash commit -- not updating HEAD
Automatic merge went well; stopped before committing as requested

 Text Editor

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<body>
<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<h1>M3</h1>
<h1>M4</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch_A-->
<h1>A1</h1>
<h1>A2</h1>
<!-- /Branch_A-->

<!-- Branch_B-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch_B-->
</body>

 The changes are also staged. To check the status, run the $ git status command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git status

You can see that git_branch_practice.html was modified and staged (ready to commit).

 Command Line - RESPONSE

On branch master
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
        modified:   git_branch_practice.html

 

2. Make a commit

As the $ git merge --squash command doesn't create a new commit in a normal setting, you need to run the $ git commit command to make a record like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "Merge Branch_A (Squash)"

You can see that a new commit is created like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

[master 294e3af] Merge Branch_A (Squash)
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 

3. Check commit histories and branch status

Check the status on the master branch first. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

You can see that a new commit is created, however, there are not A1 and A2 in the commit history. This means that the squash option combined (squashed) all the changes made on the merging branch to simplify the line of commit history.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

294e3af (HEAD -> master) Merge Branch_A (Squash)
0cbd7c0 M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

Next, check the status on Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A
$ git log --oneline

You can see that nothing has changed for Branch_A

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

fields.title: Rebase Branch ‚Äî Git Rebase
fields.content:
$ git rebase is the command when you want to reapply commits on top of another base branch. This command is useful when you want to streamline commits diverged into multiple branches. The rebase operation can also be done through a Remote Repository on the GitHub website. It is an option of merge feature of GitHub.

One the command line, you need to run the command on the branch to be rebased (a diverged branch) and designate its base branch name as a command parameter. 

$ git rebase [base branch name]

The rebase command changes the diverged point to the HEAD of the base branch. It doesn't impact the base branch itself. If you want to integrate the changes into the base branch (e.g., master branch), you need to run the merge command on the base branch side. The merge action will be Fast-forward merge as the diverged branch is already ahead of the HEAD of the base branch.

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file

In the practice on the previous page, we merged Branch_A with the master branch with the squash option. To move back to the status, reset the merge operation by running $ git reset --hard command on the master branch to reverse the HEAD of the master branch to commit M4. Use the Commit Hash of commit M4 which is generated on your computer. Also, make sure using the "--hard" option. If you don't use the option, the status of Working Tree, Staging Area and HEAD will be mixed.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git reset --hard 0cbd7c0
$ git log --oneline

You'll see that the HEAD of the master branch is back to Commit M4.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

0cbd7c0 (HEAD -> master) M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

Next, create commit M5 to align with the illustration on the left of the main slide. Edit the html file (add <h1>M5</h1> and run the $ git commit command. To check the latest status, run $ git log command again.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<h1>M3</h1>
<h1>M4</h1>
<h1>M5</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "M5"
$ git log --oneline

Finally, you'll see the following status, which is aligned with the illustration on the left of the main slide for the master branch.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

354a66d (HEAD -> master) M5
0cbd7c0 M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

Check the status of Branch_A. 

  Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A
$ git log --oneline

As we haven't touched Branch_A, its status remains the same. Branch_A is diverged at commit M3 of the master branch, which is aligned with the original position of Topic Branch on the illustration of the left of the main slide.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

b15e35a (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2
3c6b00d A1
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

2. Run the rebase command

Now you are ready to execte the rebase command. As you are already on Branch_A, run the following command. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git rebase master

You can see that Branch_A was successfully rebased.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Successfully rebased and updated refs/heads/Branch_A.

To check the latesst status of Branch_A, run the $ git log command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

Now you can see that Branch_A was rebased to the HEAD of the master branch (commit M5). In this operation, you can also confirm that the Commit Hashes for commit A1 and A2 are different from the original ones although the committed file versions remain the same. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

f3174bc (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2
6b2c99f A1
354a66d (master) M5
0cbd7c0 M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

 

3. Run the merge command

The rebase command changed Branch_A status, however, the master branch stays the same; its HEAD is still at commit M5. If you want to integrate the change in Branch_A into the master branch, you need to run the merge command.  

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git merge Branch_A

In this case, the merge operation becomes Fast-forward as Branch_A is reattached to the HEAD of the master.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Updating 354a66d..f3174bc
Fast-forward
 git_branch_practice.html | 3 ++-
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 To check the latesst status of the master branch, run the $ git log command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

Now you can see that the HEAD of the master branch move forward to the same position as the HEAD of Branch_A; the status of the master branch and Branch_A became the same.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

f3174bc (HEAD -> master, Branch_A) A2
6b2c99f A1
354a66d M5
0cbd7c0 M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

fields.title: Managing Conflict
fields.content:
If you work with another developer in the same project and edit the same file on different branches simultaneously, both of you may change the same line in the same file. In this case, it is hard to judge which one becomes the master code. This situation is called a conflict. Another case of a conflict is the case that one developer deleted a file while another developer continued working on the file.

If you try to merge the branches with a conflict, the Git system cannot complete the merge operation automatically. In that case, the Git system creates an alert identifying the location of the conflict through the registered text editor.

The flow chart below is illustrating typical cases when you run the $ git merge command. 

 

  1. Run the $ git merge command to trigger the merge process.
  2. When there is no conflict, the Git system automatically complete the merge process.
  3. When there is a conflict, the Git system suspends the automatic merge process. At this point, the merge process is still running manually; the editted files are staged during this process so that the files are ready to be commmited.
  4. If you want to stop the merge operation, run the $ git merge --abort command. When you run the command, the merge operation is aborted and the status of working files and branches will be back to the status before running the $ git merge command
  5. If you want to resolve the conflict and continue the merge operation, edit the conflicted lines of code to resolve the conflict.
  6. When the conflict is resolved, you can run the $ git commit command to complete the merge operation

 

Key Point for

4

To resolve the conflict, the Git system suggests four options through the registered text editor like the image below. If you click one of the first three options, the changes are reflected into the text editor. If you click the last "Compare Changes" option, a read-mode text editor launches to show the comparison of the two branches.

  1. Accept Current Change (Keep the changes on the branch where you are executing the merge command)
  2. Accept Incoming Change (Keep the changes on the branch being merged)
  3. Accept Both (Keep the both changes)
  4. Compare Changes

If nono of option 1-3 doesn't give what you want, you can also edit code further to customize the conflict resolution.

 

Key Point for

2

As explain, the edits done on the conflicted files during the merge process are staged. To check the status, you can run the $ git status command, you can see that the modified files are staged already (ready for commit).

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file: create a conflict

At the end of the practice on the previous page, the master branch and Branch_A became the same status. Check the latest status by running the $ git log command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git log --oneline

You'll see that the HEAD of both the master branch and Branch_A is commit A2.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

f3174bc (HEAD -> master, Branch_A) A2
6b2c99f A1
354a66d M5
0cbd7c0 M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

To create a conflict, first, revese the master branch to commit M5 by running $ git reset --hard command. Use the Commit Hash of commit M5 which is generated on your computer. Also, make sure using the "--hard" option. If you don't use the option, the status of Working Tree, Staging Area and HEAD will be mixed.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git reset --hard 354a66d
$ git log --oneline

You'll see that the HEAD of the master branch is back to Commit M5.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

HEAD is now at 354a66d M5

Next, edit the file like below by adding <h1>M6</h1> after <!-- Branch_A-->, which is supposed to be the editing area for Branch_A. And run the $ git commit command.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch_A-->
<h1>M6</h1>
<!-- /Branch_A-->

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "M6"
$ git log --oneline

 You can see that the HEAD of the master branch is now at commit M6.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

a91b5d1 (HEAD -> master) M6
354a66d M5
0cbd7c0 M4
33e8f0c M3
afdcd4c M2
5a335b9 M1

 

2. Run the merge command: confirm a conflict

Now you can run the merge command expecting there is a conflict.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git merge Branch_A

You'll see a message saying "Automatic merge failed" in the command line.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Auto-merging git_branch_practice.html
CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in git_branch_practice.html
Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.

Also, a text editor is launched when you encounter a conflict indicating the location of the conflict like below.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch_A-->
<<<<<<< HEAD
<h1>M6</h1>
=======
<h1>A1</h1>
<h1>A2</h1>
>>>>>>> Branch_A
<!-- /Branch_A-->

3. Resolve a conflict

The launched text editor also shows some options to resolve the conflict like the image below.

To resolve the conflict, you can choose one of the options which the text editor is suggesting or you can customize the edits further. In this practice, we customize the edit like below; move  <h1>M6</h1> to after <!-- Master Branch -->.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<h1>M3</h1>
<h1>M4</h1>
<h1>M5</h1>
<h1>M6</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch_A-->
<h1>A1</h1>
<h1>A2</h1>
<!-- /Branch_A-->

At this stage, the change is not reflected to any commit. To check the status, run the $ git status command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git status

The command line response gives two options: 1) fix conflicts commit the file or 2) abort the merge operation.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

On branch master
You have unmerged paths.
  (fix conflicts and run "git commit")
  (use "git merge --abort" to abort the merge)

Unmerged paths:
  (use "git add <file>..." to mark resolution)
        both modified:   git_branch_practice.html

To complete merge operation, let's make a new commit. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git commit -am "Merge Branch_A (fixed conflict)"
$ git log --oneline --graph

Now you can see that Branch_A was successfully merged with the master branch like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

*   f1e5a53 (HEAD -> master) Merge Branch_A (fixed conflict)
|\  
| * f3174bc (Branch_A) A2
| * 6b2c99f A1
* | a91b5d1 M6
|/  
* 354a66d M5
* 0cbd7c0 M4
* 33e8f0c M3
* afdcd4c M2
* 5a335b9 M1

fields.title: Stash Changes ‚Äî Git Stash
fields.content:
$ git stash is used to separately manage WIP (Work In Progress) codes. When you want to switch the current branch in the middle of editing the Working Tree and INDEX, the edits can prevent from switching the current branch (refer the $ git checkout page). In that case, this command is useful. The stashed lines of code are parked somewhere temporarily and make the Working Tree and INDEX clean (the Working Tree and INDEX status becomes the same as HEAD) so that you can switch branches.

Key Git Stash Commands

$ git stash: stash the Working Tree and INDEX

$ git stash save "[stash message]": stash the Working Tree and INDEX with a stash message

$ git stash list: list up stashed items

$ git stash apply [stash number]: restore a stashed item

$ git stash pop [stash number]: restore a stashed item and delete it from the stash list

$ git stash drop [stash number]: delete a stashed item

$ git stash clear: delete all the stashed items

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Prepare a practice file
