In this practice, we use the directory and file used in the practice on the Git switch page:

  • the git_branch_practice directory
  • the git_branch_practice.html file.

At the end of the practice on the Git switch page, we had two branches: the master branch and Branch_A with the following status.

The master branch: 

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch_A-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch_A-->

Branch_A: 

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch_A-->
<h1>A1</h1>
<!-- /Branch_A-->

To test the $ stash command, edit the file on the master branch like below and save the file, but not commit the file.

The master branch: 

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch_A-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch_A-->

At this stage, the Working Tree is already ahead of the HEAD (the latest commit) of the master branch. As explained on the previous page, you cannot switch to Branch_A. You can confirm it by running $ git checkout command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A

You'll get an error message like the one below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

error: Your local changes to the following files would be overwritten by checkout:
        git_branch_practice.html
Please commit your changes or stash them before you switch branches.
Aborting

The command line response suggests two options before you switch branches.

  1. Commit the changes
  2. Stash the changes

 

2. Run the stash command: $ git stash

First, test the $ git stash command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash

You'll see that the following message. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Saved working directory and index state WIP on master: 5a335b9 M1

When you run the stash command, the editing file in the Working Tree is reverted to HEAD (the latest commit).

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

Now you can switch to Branch_A like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout Branch_A

You'll see that the following message. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Switched to branch 'Branch_A'

 

2. Check the stash status: $ git stash list

To check the list of stashed items, run the $ git stash list command.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash list

You can see that one item is stashed. stash@{0} is stash number which is used when you restore the stashed item.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

stash@{0}: WIP on master: 5a335b9 M1

 

3. Restore a stashed item: $ git stash apply or $ git stash pop

To restore a stashed item, you have two options. The $ git stash apply command simply restores the stashed item. When you run the $ git stash pop command, it restores the stashed item and deletes the stashed item from the stashed list.

In this practice, we use the $ git stash apply command. You can run the command with or without a stash number. If you don't put stash number, the latest stash is restored. Before running the command, switch back to the master branch first to see the most simple case. (You can restore the stashed items to other branches, however, it may create a conflict.)

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git checkout master
$ git stash apply or git stash apply stash@{0}

You can see that the file status is back to the one before you run the stash command like the one below.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M2</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

On the command line, you can see a message like below. This is the same response when you run the $ git status command.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

On branch master
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   git_branch_practice.html

no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

 

4. Delete a stashed item: $ git stash drop or $ git clear

When you don't need the stashed item anymore, you can delete the stashed item. To delete one stashed item, you can $ git stash drop [stash number]. If you want to clear all the stashed items, you can use $ git stash clear. In this practice, we use $ git stash drop. If you don't designate a stash number, the command delete the latest stash.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash drop or git stash drop [stash@{0}]

You'll see that a message like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Dropped refs/stash@{0} (34989bc411fd46c49311e7e705ae6aae1f380b78)

 

4. Manage multiple stash items

When you create multiple stashed items, you may be confused about what is each stash number about. To avoid confusion, you can add a simple stash message when you stash changes by running the $ git stash save "[stash message]" command. 

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash save "M2"

You'll see that a message like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Saved working directory and index state On master: M2

Edit the html file again by adding <h1>M3</h1> this time.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1</h1>
<h1>M3</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

 Run the $ git stash save command with a stash message of "M3".

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash save "M3"

Repeat the same process for M4 and M5. And check the stash list.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash list

You can see that the four stashed items are created like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

stash@{0}: On master: M5
stash@{1}: On master: M4
stash@{2}: On master: M3
stash@{3}: On master: M2

The stash message is useful especially when you delete stashed items. As the stash numbers can change when you delete stashed items. Try the following commands to see the result.

 Command Line - INPUT

$ git stash drop
$ git stash list

You can see that stash@{0} now refers M4. It was previously M5.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

stash@{0}: On master: M4
stash@{1}: On master: M3
stash@{2}: On master: M2

fields.title: Chapter 7. Remote Collaboration
fields.content:
In this chapter, we’ll explain how to collaborate with others in a project through a Remote Repository on GitHub. Topics covered in this chapter are the following.

TOPICS

  1. Git Regular Workflow — Remote Collaboration
  2. Remote Collaboration Overview
  3. Link With Remote Repository — Git Remote
  4. Upload To Remote Repository — Git Push
  5. Download Remote Repository and Merge to Local Repository — Git Pull
  6. Get Remote Repository Information to Local Repository — Git Fetch
  7. Pull vs. Fetch
  8. Request For Review and Merge — Pull Request
  9. Merge Operation On GitHub

To start learning, go to the next page.

fields.title: Git Regular Workflow ‚Äî Remote Collaboration
fields.content:
The goal of this section is to help you fully understand how to collaborate with others through a Remote Repository on GitHub.

There are two aspects you need to learn about remote collaboration:

  1. Key Git Commands
  2. GUI (Graphic User Interface) operations on the GitHub website

1. Key Git commands

In this chapter, we'll cover four key Git commands.

  • $ git remote: this command is a multi-use command relating to manage a Remote Repository. For example, with the $ git remote add command, you can establish a link between a Remote
    Repository and a Local Repository. The git remote -v command shows the status of the link.
  • $ git push: with this command, you can upload project directories and files along with commit histories for a designated branch from your computer to a Remote Repository
  • $ git pull: with this command, you can download project directories and files along with commit histories for a designated branch from a Remote Repository. This command also merges the downloaded branch with an existing branch under the Local Repository.
  • $ git fetch: with this command, you can obtain the latest Remote Repository information and store it in your local computer. This command doesn't enforce merge branches in the Local Repository. If you want to update the Local Repository, you need to run the $ git merge or $ git checkout command. 

2. GUI operations on the GitHub website

In this chapter, we'll cover two key features of GitHub.

  • Pull request: this feature is used to ask a reviewer to review your edits. It is especially used when you want to ask the reviewer to merge your branch (a topic branch) to the main branch (e.g., master branch).
  • Merge: this feature gives similar functionality as the $ git merge command and the $ git rebase command. You can execute merge or rebase operations on the GitHub website. There are three merge approaches. 1) Create a merge commit, 2) Squash and merge, 3) Rebase and merge.

fields.title: Remote Collaboration Overview
fields.content:
In a typical remote collaboration, you need to work on both your local computer (i.e., the command line and a text editor) and a Remote Repository on the GitHub website seamlessly.

The following is the one of the typical flow of the remote collaboration on Git & GitHub. The first three steps have been already explained in detail in Chapter 4. If you want to review more detail steps, go back to Chapter 4.

A typical cycle of remote collaboration

  1. Developer A, a projedt leader and the owner of the Remote Repository, establishes a link between his Local Repository and the Remote Repository used for the project. To establish the connection, he runs the $ git remote command.
  2. Once Develop A's Local Repository is linked with the Remote Repository, he can push his project directory to the Remote Repsitory by running the $ git push command. He also gives Developer B access to the repository at this point.
  3. After Developer B obtained access to the Remote Repository, she can bring the project directory from the repository by running the $ git clone command. $ git clone command establishes link between the Remote Repository and her Local Repository, and the command also create a copy of the project direcotry on her local computer 
  4. From the second time to get project files from the Remote Repository, there are two approaches: 1) Running the $ git pull command, 2) Running the $ git fetch command followed by the $ git merge command. The $ git pull command works as the $ git fetch command and $ git merge command. $ git pull command is usefull to save time, however, there are some cases you need to run the $ git fetch command. It will be explained later.
  5. Once Developer B obtained the project directory under master branch, she is ready to make her edits (e.g., adding a new feature of the program). To start her editting, she creates a new branch (topic branch) to separate from the main line of code development. After that, she edits the code on the new branch and creates a commit when her work is done.
  6. To share the editted code under the topic branch, Developer B pushes the branch into the Remote Repository by running the $ git push command.
  7. At this stage, the code editted by Developer B is not integrated into the master branch yet. Before integrating it, she asks Developer A to review the code and ask to merge it into the master branch through Pull Request. Pull Request is a form on the GitHub to create a request to a reviewer to review code and to merge it with the main branch (e.g., master branch).
  8. Once Developer A recieved Pull Request, he reviews the code and make a judgement if the new code is ready to merge or it still requires further edits. If further edits are required, he gives Developer B a feedback on her code.
  9. If the code developed by Developer B is already ready to merge, Developer A merges the topic branch into the master branch on the GitHub website. 

 

This section gives you information about how to prepare for practices in this chapter. Actual practice will start from the next page.

Accounts used in the practice explanation

To fully understand the remote collaboration approach with Git and GitHub, you need to understand at least from two different users' perspectives: the owner of the Remote Repository and a collaborator of the Remote Repository. In this chapter, we'll use the following two users: Developer A and Developer B.

The roles and account infomation details are described in the illustration below.

 

If there are two roles in the practice section on the same page, we'll use the following drop-shadow boxes to make clear from which perspective we are explaining the section.

 Action by Developer A

Describe Developer A's actions here

 

 Action by Developer B

Describe Developer B's actions here

 

Commit history rules for this practice

For a practice purpose, we set a rule for commit messages to follow how each commit is made easily. We use the four codes like below. 

M2LB (an example)

M: which branch (e.g., M is Master, A is Branch A)

2: commit number (e.g., 2 is the second commit on the branch)

L: Local vs. Remote (L is commited in the Local Repository, R is committed in the Remote Repository)

B: who committed (e.g., A is Developer A, B is Developer B)

We also put the commit message in the file to be committed so that you can easily link between the commit and the edited contents.

 

Building a practice environment

In the real life situation, different developers are using different GitHub accounts and different computers. An ideal practice einvironment is to imitate the situation, however, it may not be realistic to fully imitate the situation. There are some options you can think of:

Option 1: The most ideal option

  • Remote: Creaete two GitHub accounts (you need two email accounts as well)
  • Local: Create two user accounts on your computer (you need to switch accounts when changing roles)

Option 2: The second best option 

  • Remote: Creaete two GitHub account (you need two email accounts as well)
  • Local: Create two parent project directories

Option 3: The minimum option

  • Remote: Creaete one GitHub account
  • Local: Create two parent project directories

 

Creating two parent project directories

Option 1 is closer to the real-life situation, however, it takes some time and efforts, especially to setup different user accounts on your computer. If you want to avoid it, you can create two parent project directories on your computer like the illustration below.

(The illustration below is an example of the practice environment setup based on option 2 with two GitHub accounts.)

 

Under each of the parent project directories, you can create a project directory where you can establish its own Local Repository. The image below is for showing an example. Actual directory setup will be explained on the next page.

You also need to launch two text editors and command lines in different windows. To launch them, you can drag & drop the parent directory onto your text editor application like below to open the directory with the editor and the command line terminal.

You can open the two text editors with the command line terminal side by side like below.

fields.title: Link With Remote Repository ‚Äî Git Remote
fields.content:
$ git remote is the command used when you want to establish and check a linking status between a Remote Repository and your Local Repository. There are some derivative commands and options of this command. We'll explain five major usages on this page.

 

Key Git Remote Commands

$ git remote add: Establish a link with a Remote Repository

$ git remote -v: Check the status of the linked Remote Repository

$ git remote rm: Delete the Remote Repository link

$ git remote set-url: Change the Remote Repository URL

$ git remote rename: Change the Remote Repository name

 

1. $ git remote add: establish a link with a Remote Repository

As explained in Chapter 4, when you launch a project as a owner of the Remote Repository, you need to upload your project directory to the Remote Repository first. Before pushing the code, you need to establish a link between your Local Repository and the Remote Repository. The command to estabilsh the link is $ git remote add. You need to designate a Remote Repository name and Remote Repository URL like the one below. The Remote Repository name is typically origin. The URL is the one you can get from the Remote Repository page on GitHub. For more details, refer Chapter 4.

$ git remote add [Remote Repository name] [Remote Repository URL]

 

2. $ git remote -v: check registereed Remote Repositories

This command can be more frequently used. After you create a link with a Remote Repository by running the $ git remote add command or the $ git clone command, you may want to check the status of the link. $ git remote -v is the command to check the status of the Remote Repository linked with your Local Repository. This command doesn't require any parameters like below.

$ git remote -v

 

3. $ git remote rm: delete the Remote Repository link

When you want to change the current Remote Repository to another repository, you may want to deregister the link with the Remote Repository. The $ git remote rm command is used for that case. To run the command, you need to designate the Remote Repository name like the one below. 

$ git remote rm [Remote Repository name]

 

4. $ git remote set-url: change the Remote Repository URL

When you want to change SSH connection to HTTPS connection or simply you want to change the URL of the Remote Repository, you can run the $ git remote set-url command. When you run the command, you need to designate the existing Remote Repository name and new URL.

$ git remote set-url [existing Remote Repository name] [new URL]

 

5. $ git remote rename: change the Remote Repository name

Typical name of a Remote Repository is origin. However, there may be a situation that you want to use a different name for the Remote Repository such as managing multiple Remote Repositories at the same time. You can change the Remote Repository name by running the $ git remote rename command.

$ git remote rename [existing Remote Repository name] [new Remote Repository name]

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

 Action by Developer A

All actions described below are done from Developer A(project leader)'s point of view

1. Prepare a practice file

For this practice, we'll use the following directory and file. These directory and file will be used throughout the practices in this chapter.

  • Directory: git_remote_practice
  • File: git_remote_practice.html

To create the directory and file, run the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

mkdir git_remote_practice
cd git_remote_practice
touch git_remote_practice.html

For the html file, edit like below. We'll use four branches. For the practice purposes, create coding spaces for each branch. For the first commit on the master branch, add <h1>M1LA</h1> after <!-- Master Branch-->. M1LA indicates the following for a practice purpose; M: Master Branch, 1: the first commit, L: on the Local branch, A: edited by Developer A).

 Text Editor

<!doctype html>
<html lang="en">
<body>
<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1LA</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch A-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch A-->

<!-- Branch B-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch B-->

<!-- Branch C-->
N/A
<!-- /Branch C-->
</body>

As we are working on a new directory, we need to create a new Local Repository. Also, let's make the first commit with the commit message of "M1LA", and check the commit status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git init
git add .
git commit -am "M1LA"
git log --oneline

You can see that the first commit is successfully made.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

ee8f530 (HEAD -> master) M1LA

 

2. Create a Remote Repository

Next, create a new Remote Repository for this practice. Go to the GitHub website and log into your account. Click the + button on top right and select New repository. You'll reach to the page like below. Add Repository name (use the same name as your project directory (git_remote_practice) to avoid confusion. 

After you press the green button to creaet a new repository, you'll see the following Quick setup page. First, we try to use SSH connection. Copy the URL by clicking the bottun on the right.

 Go back to the command line and run the $ git remote add command with a Remote Repository name (typically, "origin" is used) and the URL copied on the GitHub website. Also, run $ git remote -v command to check the Remote Repository status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git remote add origin git@github.com:bloovee/git_remote_practice.git
git remote -v

You can see that the Remote Repository is successfully registered in your Local Repository.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

origin  git@github.com:bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (push)

 

3. Delete a Remote Repository link

To delete the Repository Repository link, run the $ git remote rm command like below. Also, run $ git remote -v command to check the status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git remote rm origin
git remote -v

There will be no response as the Remote Repository is already deleted.

For the next step, add the Remote Repository again.

 Command Line - INPUT

git remote add origin git@github.com:bloovee/git_remote_practice.git
git remote -v

Confirme that the Remote Repository is correctly registered.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

origin  git@github.com:bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (fetch)
origin  git@github.com:bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (push)

 

4. Change the Remote Repository URL

In this practice, we try to change the Remote Repository URL from SSH to HTTPS. First, get the new URL from the Remote Repository. Click the HTTPS button and click the right button to copy the URL.

 Run the $ git remote set-url command with the copied URL. Also, run the $ git remote -v command to confirm the status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git remote set-url origin https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git
git remote -v

 You can see that the URL changed to HTTPS URL.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

origin  https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (fetch)
origin  https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (push)

 

 5. Change the Remote Repository name

Lastly, try to change the Remote Repository name. This time change the name from "origin" to "origin_2" like below. 

 Command Line - INPUT

git remote rename origin origin_2
git remote -v

You can see that the name has changed to "origin_2".

 Command Line - RESPONSE

origin_2  https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (fetch)
origin_2  https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (push)

For the next practice, reverse the name to "origin".

 Command Line - INPUT

git remote rename origin_2 origin
git remote -v

Confirm the name is changed back to "origin".

 Command Line - RESPONSE

origin  https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (fetch)
origin  https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git (push)

fields.title: Upload To Remote Repository ‚Äî Git Push
fields.content:
Push is used when you want to reflect changes in the Local Repository to the Remote Repository. After establishing a link between the Remote Repository and the Local Repository by the $ git remote add command or the $ git clone command, you can upload your changes into the linked Remote Repository by running the $ git push command. 

When you push a branch, you need to specify the branch name after the Remote Repository name. Typically, origin is used for a Remote Repository name. The following is an example when you push the master branch to the Remote Repository. (This standard command is already explained in Chapter 4.)

$ git push origin master

Mainly there are two cases in the push operation. 

  1. Push an existing branch (the branch exists in both the Local Respsitory and the Remote Repository.
  2. Push a new branch (the branch created in the Local Repository, however, it doesn't exist in the Remote Repository)

 

1. Push an existing brandh

In this case, when you run the push command, the branch is uploaded to the Remote Repository, and Fast-Forward merge is triggered unless the pushed branch doesn't create conflicts.

2. Push a new branch

In this case, when you run the push command, the pushed branch is generated in the Remote Repository. 

3. Conflicts

When you push a branch to the Remote Repository, Git checks if the pushed branch creates a conflict. If there is any conflict, the push operation is terminated. 

You'll see an error messge like the one below when you encounter a conflict.

For example, you'll face a conflict when an advanced commit already exists on the same branch in the Remote Repository like Case A in the illustration below: M3R commit already exists in the Remote Repository while M3L commit in the Local Repository is being pushed.

When you are pushing a new branch it is safer. It will be like Case B in the illustration below: A1 commit in Branch A (new branch) doesn't conflict with M3R commit in the master branch unless you trigger the merge operation.

 

TIPS

The "-u" option

In the typical Git operation, you tend to repeat the push commands to upload editted files on the same branch in the same Remote Repository. To avoid typing a Remote Repository name and a branch name everytime, you can use the "-u" option or "–set-upstream" option (the meaning of upstream will be explained on the $ git fetch page). After running the command with the "-u" option, you don't need to designate a Remote Repository name and a branch name again. 

For the first push command

$ git push -u origin master

After the first command (no need to type origin and master anymore)

$ git push

 

4. After the push operation

When you push your code to the Remote Repository, other developers who have access to the Remote Repository (collaborators) can see it on the GitHub website and download it to their local computer by the $ git pull or $ git fetch command. You can also ask one of the collaborators to review and merge to a main branch (e.g., master branch) by triggering Pull Request.

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

 Action by Developer A

All actions described below are done from Developer A(project leader)'s point of view

1. Prepare a practice file

Use the same file as the previous practice on the previous page (the $ git remote page). We already made one commit on the master branch. If you haven't prepared the file, go back to the previous page.

 

2. Push a file to an existing branch

As the URL of the Remote Repository is already registered, you are ready to run the push command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin master

When you run the command, the command line may ask to type your password. For HTTPS connection, you need to use PAT (Personal Access Token) explained in Chapter 4. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
To https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git
 * [new branch]      master -> master

Go to the Remote Repository on the GitHub website. After refresning the browser, you can see that the project directory git_remote_practice is successfully uploaded to the Remote Repository like below.

 

3. Create conflicted commits on the Local and Remote Repositories

This section is just for a practice puroose. We'll explain in what condition you cannot execute the push command.

First, make a new commit directly on the Remote Repository.

On the Remote Repository, click git_remote_practice.html file

You can see the contents of the html file like below. Press the pen mark on the right to edit the file.

 Edit the file like below (adding <h1>M2RA</h1>).

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1LA</h1>
<h1>M2RA</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

Go the the bottom of the site and add a commit message. In this practice, put "M2RA". M2RA indicates the following for a practice purpose; M: Master branch, 2: the second commit, R: on the Remote branch, A: edited by Developer A. Select "commit directly to the master branch" and click the green button to commit the change.

Now, go back to the editor on your local computer and edit like below (the same edit as the one on the Remote Repository).

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1LA</h1>
<h1>M2LA</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

Commit the change with the commit message of "M2LA". M2LA indicates the following for a practice purpose; M: Master branch, 2: the second commit, L: on the Local branch, A: edited by Developer A. And run the $ git log command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "M2LA"
git log --oneline

You can see that the commit history like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

06986d6 (HEAD -> master) M2LA
ee8f530 (origin/master) M1LA

The current stuation is similar to Case A explained in the beginig of this page. 

Run the $ git push command to see the result.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin master

As there is a commit M2RA in the Remote Repository already, the push command is rejected.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

To https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git
 ! [rejected]        master -> master (fetch first)
:

 

4. Push a file to a new branch

As we cannot push the change to the master branch, create a new branch Branch_A and checkout to the branch. To comfirm the commit history on the branch, also run $ git log command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout -b Branch_A
git log --oneline

You can see that the status of Branch_A status is the same as the status of the master branch.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

06986d6 (HEAD -> Branch_A, master) M2LA
ee8f530 (origin/master) M1LA

Currently, Branch_A doesn't exist on the Remote Repository. Push Branch_A to see the result.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin Branch_A

You can see that Branch_A was successfully pushed to the Remote Repository although the code of the master branch and Branch_A are the same. This is because you can avoid clashing code on the same branch and give a room to reconcile on the Remote Repository later.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 9, done.
:
 * [new branch]      Branch_A -> Branch_A

Go to the Remote Repository on the GitHub website; exit from the code browsing mode by clicking the git_remote_practice repository. You can confirm that Branch_A was created on the browser like below.

 

5. Clean up the master branch conflict

As we intentionally created conflicted commits commit M2LA and M2RA in the Local Repository and the Remote Repository. Let's clean up then before going to the next practice. We'll clean up the commits and branches like the image below.

 

First, clean up Branch_A

Currently, Branch_A and the master branch are the same. We want to create a unique code for Branch_A for a practice purpose. 

Rest commit histories to commit M1LA on Branch_A. This is for recreating Branch_A from the first commit of the master branch as commit M2LA is conflicting with M2RA in the Remote Repository. To execute $ git reset, use a Commit Hash generated on your computer for commit M1LA.

 Command Line - INPUT

git reset --hard ee8f530

You can see that the HEAD is back to M1LA.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

HEAD is now at ee8f530 M1LA

Now create a correct version of Branch_A. Edit the html file like below (adding <h1>A1LA</h1> after <!-- Branch A-->. A1LA indicates the following for a practice purpose; A: Branch_A, 1: the first commit, L: on the Local branch, A: edited by Developer A.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1LA</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

<!-- Branch A-->
<h1>A1LA</h1> 
<!-- /Branch A-->

Commit the change with the commit message of "A1LA" and check the log.

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "A1LA"
git log --oneline

You can see that the HEAD of Branch_A is now A1LA and it is diverged from the master branch at commit M1LA.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

d0a90aa (HEAD -> Branch_A) A1LA
ee8f530 (origin/master) M1LA


 As Branch_A on the Remote Repository is still old status, go to the Remote Repository and delete it to avoid a conflict. This is for a practice purpose. You need to carefully manage the process when deleting a branch on the Remote Repository.

To delete a branch, press the branch selection pull down on the left and click View all branches.

Click the delete button on Branch_A like the one below.

You can see that Branch_A was successfully deleted like below.

To update Branch_A on the Remote Repository, push Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin Branch_A

You can see that Branch_A was pushed successfully.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 6, done.
:
 * [new branch]      Branch_A -> Branch_A

You can also confirm that the latest commit is A1LA on the Remote Repository like the image below.

 

Next, clean up the master branch

Switch the current branch to the master branch and check the log.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout master
git log --oneline

You can see that M2LA, which is conflicting with the one on the Remote Repository, is still the HEAD of the master branch as we reset it only on Branch_A.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

06986d6 (HEAD -> master) M2LA
ee8f530 (origin/master) M1LA

Reset the master branch to commit M1LA. Use the Commit Hash generated on your computer for commit M1LA.

 Command Line - INPUT

git reset --hard ee8f530

You can see that the HEAD of the master branch is now back to M1LA.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

HEAD is now at ee8f530 M1LA

fields.title: Download Remote Repository and Merge to Local Repository ‚Äî Git Pull
fields.content:
Pull is used when you want to download the latest remote repository information and merge with the existing branch in the Local Repository. $ git pull is the commaned used to execute the pull action. The $ git pull command is often explained as a shortcut command of $ git fetch and $ git merge. As $ git pull command shortcuts to check the Remote Repository information manually, it may create a conflict. For a simple operation, you can use the pull command. However, generally, it is safer to use the $ git fetch command and check the Remote Reopository status first before executing the $ git merge command.

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

In this practice, we'll use the following two different users: Developer A and Developer B. 

1. Download the project files first time: $ git clone

This is a recap of Chapter 4. If we are already familiar with the process, you can skip this part.

 Action by Developer A

Before Developer B access the Remote Repository, Developer A needs to grant access.

Go Settings of the repository and select Manage access. Press the green button to add people. 

Find the collaborator. In this demo, we invite sky-blue2022 (Developer B).

 

 

Next explain from the Developer B point of view.

 Action by Developer B

After Developer A send an invitation. Developer B receives an email of the invitation like below.

Click View invitation and press the Access invitation button like the image below.

Now you have access to the Remote Repository. To clone the project file, click the Code button and copy the URL for HTTPS.

Go to the command line and run the $ git clone command like below. When you run the command, make sure that the current directory is where you want to creat the project directory.

 Command Line - INPUT

git clone https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice.git

If the commad is successfuly go through like below, you'll see that git_remote_practice directory is generated under the directory you executed the clone command.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Cloning into 'git_remote_practice'...
:
Resolving deltas: 100% (2/2), done.

 

2. Pull a branch: $ git pull

At this stage, the HEAD of the master branch in each repository are the following.

  • Remote Repository: M2RA
  • Developer A's Local Repository: M1LA
  • Developer B's Local Repository: M2RA

From Developer B's point of view, at this stage, the statuses of the Remote Repository and the Local Repository on the master branch are the same; the HEAD is commit M2RA. This means that there is nothing you can pull on the master branch. However, Developer A's master branch lags behind.

To practice the pull command, we'll do the following actions

  1. Pull the master branch on Developer A's local computer
  2. Further edit the master branch on Developer A's computer and push it to the Remote Repository
  3. Pull the updated master branch on Developer B's local computer

 Action by Developer A

Run the pull command designating the Remote Repository name (origin) and the master branch.

 Command Line - INPUT

git pull origin master

You can see that the master branch was updated by the Fast-forward merge.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

bloovee@MBP git_remote_practice % git pull origin master
remote: Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
Fast-forward
 git_remote_practice.html | 3 ++-
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 To confirm the commit status, check the log.

 Command Line - INPUT

git log --oneline

You can see that the HEAD of the master branch in Developer A's Local Repository is the same as the Remote Repository's.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

a4e2c2f (HEAD -> master, origin/master) M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

Next, edit the html file on the master branch.

 Text Editor

<!-- Master Branch-->
<h1>M1LA</h1>
<h1>M2RA</h1>
<h1>M3LA</h1>
<!-- /Master Branch-->

 Commit the change with the commit message of "M3LA" and check the log to see the latest status. (M3LA indicates the following for a practice purpose; M: Master Branch, 1: the third commit, L: on the Local branch, A: edited by Developer A.)

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "M3LA"
git log --oneline

You can see that a new commit is successfully created like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

de2bca2 (HEAD -> master) M3LA
a4e2c2f (origin/master) M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

 Finally, push the master branch to the Remote Repository.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin master

You can see that a latest commit is successfully pushed like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
   a4e2c2f..de2bca2  master -> master

 

Next explain from the Developer B point of view.

 Action by Developer B

 Before running the pull command, let's check the commit status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git log --oneline

You can see only two commits at this stage.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

a4e2c2f (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD) M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

To bring the latest commit made by Developer A to Developer B's Local Repository, run the pull command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git pull origin master

You can see that Fast-forward merge was executed.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

remote: Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
 * branch            master     -> FETCH_HEAD
   a4e2c2f..de2bca2  master     -> origin/master
Updating a4e2c2f..de2bca2
Fast-forward
 git_remote_practice.html | 1 +
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+)

Check the commit status again.

 Command Line - INPUT

git log --oneline

You can see that commit M3LA made by Developer A was merged with Developer B's master branch.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

de2bca2 (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD) M3LA
a4e2c2f M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

 

3. Recap of this practice page

To check the summary of what we have done, you can check the illustration below.

fields.title: Get Remote Repository Information to Local Repository ‚Äî Git Fetch
fields.content:
Fetch is used when you want to get the latest status of the Remote Repository. The command used to execute Fetch is $ git fetch. The command doesn’t require a branch name. You’ll get the information for all branches under the Remote Repository. To check the Remote Repository branch status, run the $ git branch -a command. The command with the -a option shows the branch status of the Remote Repository tracked by the local computer.

There are two major usage for $ git fetch.

1. To bring new branch from the Remote Repository

 As explained on the previous page, $ git pull command doen't work for a new branch. The Fetch command is useful when a new branch is created in a remote repository and bring it to your Local Repository. The typical command procees is as follows.

First, run the fetch command to get the remote repository data.

$ git fetch origin¬†

Then, check the branch name you want to get.

$ git branch -a

Finally, switch to the new branch you want to move by running the $ git checkout or $ git switch command.

$ git checkout [branch name]

 

2. To update an existing branch by the latest status of the Remote Repository

You can use the $ git pull command to update an existing branch, however, if you are not sure that the branch status in the Remote Repository, you can run the $ git fetch command first followed by the $ merge command as follows.

First, run the fetch command to get the remote repository data.

$ git fetch origin¬†

Then, run the merge command from the branch you want to update. For the parameter, add "origin/" before the branch name you want to update.

$ git merge origin/[Local Repository name]

 

Note:

To have better understanding on the role of Fetch, understanding the two concepts may be helpful: a remote-tracking branch and an upstream branch. If you are a really beginner of Git, you can skip this section. You can come back here when you build basic understandings of Git.

  • Remote-tracking branch: the branch tracks a remote repository from the Local Repository (e.g., origin/master, origin/Branch_A)
  • Upstream branch: the remote repository tracked by the remote-tracking branch

The following explanation by the Git documentation may give you better idea about the remote-tracking branch.

"Remote-tracking branches are references to the state of remote branches. They’re local references that you can’t move; Git moves them for you whenever you do any network communication, to make sure they accurately represent the state of the remote repository. Think of them as bookmarks, to remind you where the branches in your remote repositories were the last time you connected to them.

Remote-tracking branch names take the form <remote>/<branch>. For instance, if you wanted to see what the master branch on your origin remote looked like as of the last time you communicated with it, you would check the origin/master branch. If you were working on an issue with a partner and they pushed up an iss53 branch, you might have your own local iss53 branch, but the branch on the server would be represented by the remote-tracking branch origin/iss53."

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

1. Check the limitation of the pull command

In this part, we'll explain from the point of veiw of Developer B.

 Action by Developer B

First, the current branch status by running the $ git branch command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git branch

You can see only the master branch on the Developer B's local computer. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* master

Next, check the branch status of the Remote Repository with the "-a" option. With the option, the $ git branch command give an infomation including the status of the Remote Repository captured in the Local Repository.

 Command Line - INPUT

git branch -a

Now you can see that Branch_A also exists in the Remote Repository. Branch_A was created and pushed in the practice on the git push page.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* master
  remotes/origin/Branch_A
  remotes/origin/HEAD -> origin/master
  remotes/origin/master

To try to get Branch_A in the Local Repository, run the $ git pull command like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

git pull origin Branch_A

You can see a message like below. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

From https://github.com/bloovee/git_remote_practice
 * branch            Branch_A   -> FETCH_HEAD
:
fatal: Need to specify how to reconcile divergent branches.

To confirm the latest branch status, run the $ git branch command again.

 Command Line - INPUT

git branch

You can see only the master branch. This means that $ git pull command doesn't work for a new branch which does't exist in the Local Repository yet.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* master

 

2. Bring a new branch to the Local Repository — after the pull command execution

In this part, we'll explain from the poitn of veiw of Developer B first.

 Action by Developer B

As $ git pull command executes $ git fetch command first, all branch information in the Remote Repository is brought to the Local Repository. We already confirmed it by running the $ git branch -a command. To bring a branch already exists in the Remote Repository to the Local Repository, you need to simply run $ git checkout or $ git switch command. Try the command and check the branch status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout Branch_A
git branch

You can see that Branch_A is registered under the Local Repository and it becomes the current branch.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* Branch_A
  master

 

3. Test the fetch command

As we executed $ git pull command first, the functionality of the $ git fetch command is still not clearly explained. To clearly explain it, create another branch from the repository owener side (Developer A).

 Action by Developer A

Create a new branch Branch_B and switch to the branch by running the following command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout -b Branch_B

You can confirm that the current branch is switched to the new branch Branch_B.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Switched to a new branch 'Branch_B'

Edit the html file like below (add code after <!-- Branch B-->). B1LA indicates the following for a practice purpose; B: Branch_B, 1: the first commit, L: on the Local branch, A: edited by Developer A.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch B-->
<h1>B1LA</h1>
<!-- /Branch B-->

Commit the change and check the log.

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "B1LA"
git log --oneline

You can confirm that a new commit is made on Branch_B.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

23a03f0 (HEAD -> Branch_B) B1LA
3c51257 (origin/master, master) M3LA
a4e2c2f M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

 Push the new branch Branch_B.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin Branch_B

You can confirm that the new branch Branch_B was pushed to the Remote Repository like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
 * [new branch]      Branch_B -> Branch_B

 

Let's also update Branch_A to do another test. Switch to Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

 git checkout Branch_A

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Switched to branch 'Branch_A'

 Edit the file like below (Add A2LA). A2LA indicates the following for a practice purpose; A: Branch_A, 2: the second commit, L: on the Local branch, A: edited by Developer A.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch A-->
<h1>A1LA</h1>
<h1>A2LA</h1>
<!-- /Branch A-->

 And, commit the change and check the log.

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "A2LA"
git log --oneline

 Command Line - RESPONSE

4ba3298 (HEAD -> Branch_A) A2LA
d0a90aa (origin/Branch_A) A1LA
ee8f530 M1LA

Push it to the Remote Repository.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin Branch_A

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
   d0a90aa..4ba3298  Branch_A -> Branch_A

 

Next, we'll try to bring the new commit to Developer B's Local Repository by running the $ git fetch command.

 Action by Developer B

To check the Remote Repository status in Developer B's Local Repository, run the $ git branch -a command.

 Command Line - INPUT

git branch -a

You can see that there is no infomation about Branch_B.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* Branch_A
  master
  remotes/origin/Branch_A
  remotes/origin/HEAD -> origin/master
  remotes/origin/master

 Run the $ git fetch command to update the Remote Repository informaiton.

 Command Line - INPUT

git fetch

You can see that there are two updates

  1. Branch_A is updated
  2. new branch Branch_B is created

 Command Line - RESPONSE

remote: Enumerating objects: 10, done.
:
   d0a90aa..4ba3298  Branch_A   -> origin/Branch_A
 * [new branch]      Branch_B   -> origin/Branch_B

Run the $ git branch -a command again to see the latest branch status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git branch -a

You can see that Branch_B is under the Remote Repository, however, it is still not in the Local Repository.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* Branch_A
  master
  remotes/origin/Branch_A
  remotes/origin/Branch_B
  remotes/origin/HEAD -> origin/master
  remotes/origin/master

To bring it to the Local Repository, run the $ git checkout or $ git switch command like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout Branch_B

You can see that the current branch is switched to Branch_B like below. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Branch 'Branch_B' set up to track remote branch 'Branch_B' from 'origin'.
Switched to a new branch 'Branch_B'

 

You also need to update Branch_A. Switch to Branch_A.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout Branch_A

You can see a message saying Branch_A is behind. 

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Switched to branch 'Branch_A'
Your branch is behind 'origin/Branch_A' by 1 commit, and can be fast-forwarded.
  (use "git pull" to update your local branch)

To update Branch_A, you can run the $ git pull command or the $ git merge command. For a practice purpose, we use $ git merge command here. Use "origin/Branch_A" as the parameter of the command. 

 Command Line - INPUT

git merge origin/Branch_A

You can see that the Fast-forward merge was executed.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Updating d0a90aa..4ba3298
Fast-forward
 git_remote_practice.html | 3 ++-
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

 

5. Checking the branch status

Now all repositories (Developer A's Local Repository, Developer B's Local Repository and the Remote Repository) are the same status.

To see the status of the Remote Repository, go the repository on the GitHub website. Select Branch_B on the branch selection pull down on the left and click the clock button on the right.

You can see the commit histories of the Branch_B in the Remote Repository.

To check the summary of what we have done, you can check the illustration below.

fields.title: Pull vs. Fetch
fields.content:
This page is a recap to give a comparison between Pull and Fetch.

The key difference between Pull (the $ git pull command) and Fetch (the $ git fetch command) is whether the command execute a merge action or not.

The both commands download commits and files from a remote repository under the remote-traking branches. The pull command seamlessly trigger the merge action for the designated branch, howerver, what the fetch command does is the remote-traking branches (the Remote Repository information).

Typically, the pull command is used for efficiency of operations. For a simple operation, you can use the pull command. However, generally, it is safer to use the $ git fetch command and check the Remote Reopository status first before executing the $ git merge command.

fields.title: Request For Review and Merge ‚Äî Pull Request
fields.content:
Pull Request in GitHub is used to create a request to review changes on a topic branch and merge it with a main branch (e.g., the master branch). It has nothing to do with the pull command although the naming is similar. To avoid confusion, you can memorize it as merge request. In GitLab, it is in fact called merge request.

Before triggering a Pull Request, you need to push an edited branch to a Remote Repository. After pushing the branch, you can ask a reviewer to review and merge with the main branch. You can initiate a Pull Request on the GitHub website. The Pull Request operation is typically done through a web browser.

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

The scenario of this practice is the following

  1. Developer B works on creating a new feature on a new branch Branch_C, and pushes the code to the Remote Repository
  2. Developer B triggers a Pull Request to ask Developer A to review and merge the branch to the master branch
  3. Developer A reviews the code on Branch_C and gives a feedback to Developer B
  4. Developer B modifys the code on Branch_C based on the feedback from Developer A
  5. Developer A finally approves the change on Branch_C and merges it with the master branch
  6. Developer B sees Developer A's approval

1. Create a new feature on a new branch

In this step, Developer B creates Branch_C diverged from the master branch and edits the html file as if writing code to create a new feature on the branch. Also, make some commits and push Branch_C to the Remote Repository.

 Action by Developer B

First, create a new branch Branch_C from the master branch.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout master
git checkout -b Branch_C

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Switched to a new branch 'Branch_C'

 Edit the html file like below (add <h1>C1LB</h1> after <!-- Branch C-->. C1LB indicates the following for a practice purpose; C: Branch_C, 1: the first commit, L: on the Local branch, B: edited by Developer B.)

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch C-->
<h1>C1LB</h1>
<!-- /Branch C-->

Commit the change with the commit message of "C1LB" like below.

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "C1LB"

 Command Line - RESPONSE

[Branch_C 8c3d8a0] C1LB
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+), 1 deletion(-)

Repeat the same process of editing the file and commiting the change twice. Use C2LB and C3LB for each commit respectively, and check the log to see the latest status.

 Command Line - INPUT

git log --oneline

You can see that there are three new commits on Branch_C.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

884d938 (HEAD -> Branch_C) C3LB
1fbe7ca C2LB
8c3d8a0 C1LB
de2bca2 (origin/master, origin/HEAD, master) M3LA
a4e2c2f M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

 Next, push Branch_C to the Remote Repository.

 Command Line - INPUT

git push origin Branch_C

You can see that Branch_C is successfuly pushed like below.

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 11, done.
:
 * [new branch]      Branch_C -> Branch_C

Now you can go to the next step.

 

2. Trigger a Pull Request to ask for review and merge

In this step, Developer B triggers a Pull Request to ask Developer A to review and merge the branch to the master branch.

 Action by Developer B

1) When you push a branch to the remote repository, usually a message about the push is displayed in the Remote Repository site. To start to create a new Pull Request, clikc the Compare & pull request button.

 

2) To create a Pull Request, you need to select a base branch and the branch being merged shown after "compare". In this case, Developer B selects the master branch for the base branch and Branch_C to compare. To go to the next step, press the Create pull request button.

 

3) A Pull Request has two main elements: the Pull Request message (PR message) and reviewers.

In the PR message, typically, you need to describe what is the changes about and why you are making the changes. You can write a message in markdown. You can also create a template for a PR message to standardize the message format in the team.

For reviewers, you can select multiple reviewers. In this practice demonstration, we select Developer A: bloovee.

To create the Pull Request, click the Create pull request button.

 

3. Review the code on the new branch and give a feedback

In this step, Developer A reviews the code on Branch_C and gives a feedback to Developer B.

 Action by Developer A

1) When a Pull Request is generated, the repository owener and the reviewers receive an email notification like below. In this practice demo, Developer A is the owner and the reviewer. He receives two email notifications. On the email, you can find the link of the Pull Request. Click the link to go to the next step.

An email sent to the repository owner:

An email sent to reviewers:

 

2) On the Pull Request page, there are several tabs. The Conversation tab is the one which you need to take a look first. It describes the overview of the pull request with the commit history information.

 

3) Another tab you need to check is the Files changed tab. On the tab, you can find the key changes commited by the requester (in this case, Developer B: sky-blue202122). As a reviewer, you can add review comments line by line before making an overall review message. When you click the Add single comment button, the message is immediately going to the Conversation section so that other team members can see it. When you want to make a more comprehensive review, clidk the Start a review button.

 

4) After starting a review, you can continue to review line by line. When you are ready to finish the review, click the Finish your review button.

 

5) When you clidk the Finish your review button, the final review comment window pops up. You can write the final message and select one of three types of review.

  • Comment: submit general feedback without explicit approval
  • Approve: submit feedback and approve merging these changes
  • Request changes: submit feedback that must be addressed before merging

In the message, you can drag and drop a file to give more detail explanation. When you completed the message and selected one of the options, click the Submit review button to finalize the review.

 

4. Modify the code and push it

In this step, Developer B modifys the code on Branch_C based on the feedback from Developer A.

 Action by Developer B

1) When the reviewer completed the review, the requester (Developer B in this case) recieves an email notification like below. Click the link to see the review comments in the Remote Repository.

 

2) You can see the review comments line by line on the browswer like below.

 

3) To fiix the error, use the local text editor and the commandline. Edit the file, make a commit and push it to the Remote Repository in the following process.

Before making an edit, make sure that you are operating on Branch_C.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout Branch_C

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Already on 'Branch_C'

Edit the file like below. Deleted C2LB and added C4LB.

 Text Editor

<!-- Branch C-->
<h1>C1LB</h1>

<h1>C3LB</h1>
<h1>C4LB</h1>
<!-- /Branch C-->

 Commit the change and push the branch.

 Command Line - INPUT

git commit -am "C4LB"
git push origin Branch_C

 Command Line - RESPONSE

Enumerating objects: 5, done.
:
   884d938..56e6a45  Branch_C -> Branch_C

 

4) After pushing the branch, go to the Remote Repository, and ask for an approval. Write comments to inform what you have done and press the Comment button to submit the comment.

 

5. Approve the edit and merges it with the master branch

In this step, Developer A finally approves the change on Branch_C and merges it with the master branch.

 Action by Developer A

1) When the requester (Developer B) resubmitted the changes and comments, the reviewer (Developer A) recieves an email notification like below. Click the link on the message or directly go to the Remote Repository.

 

2) Go to the Files changed tab to see the fixed code.

 

3) If the new code is acceptable, approve the change. On the Conversation tab, you can find the Changes requested section. click the ... button on the right to open the list. Select the Approve changes.

 

6. See the approval

 Action by Developer B

1) When the reviewer (Developer A) approved the change, the requester (Developer B) recieves an email notification like below.

2) On the Conversation tab, the Changes requested status becomes Changes approved like below. 

 

7. See the approval

To check the summary of what we have done, you can check the illustration below.

 

At this point, Branch_C is not merged yet. To see the merge operation, go to the next page.

fields.title: Merge Operation On GitHub
fields.content:
How to merge branches through the command line on the local computer is already explained in Chapter 6: Work with Branches. On this page, we'll explain how to merge branches on GitHub through a web browser.

The merge feature on GitHub gives similar functionality as the Git commands. There are three merge approaches which are the combination of the three Git commands: $ git merge, $ git rebase and $ git commit command.

  1. Create a merge commit: $ git merge --no-ff 
  2. Squash and merge: $ git merge --squash + $ git commit
  3. Rebase and merge: $ git rebase + $ git merge

1. Create a merge commit

This approach is the most commonly used approach. By this approach, the base branch captures and keeps all the commit histories from the topic branch like the left illustration on the main slide. 

2. Squash and merge

When you want to integrate all the small commits to simplify the commit history of the project, yhou take take this option. A drawback of this option is that all the commits of the topic branch are erased from the history  like the middle illustration on the main slide.

3. Rebase and merge

If you have many branches in the project and merge them into the master branch, the commit history of the project becomes very complex. This option is used to make the commit line straight  like the right illustration on the main slide.

 

For better understanding, please go through the following practice section.

In this practice, we'll go throught the three merge approaches on the GitHub based on the branches prepared on the previous pages. The target operations are illustrated below.

1. Create a merge commit: merge Branch_C into the master branch
2. Squash and merge: squash and merge Branch_A
3. Rebase and merge: rebase and merge Branch_B

 

1. Create a merge commit: merge Branch_C into the master branch

On the previous page, we have already explained about Pull Request until a reviewr approves the changes (Developer A already approved Developer B's code). 

The merge operation can be done by either sides: the requester or the approver of the Pull Request. In this step, we'll explain the case that the reviewer (Developer A) conducts the merge operation.

 Action by Developer A

1) To execute the merge operation, go the the Pull Request page created on the previous page. Select Create a merge commit in the Merge pull request pull dowon, and click the button again.

 

2) Press the Confirm merge button to execute.

 

3) A confirmation message is displayed like below.

 

4) Check the commit history on the master branch. You can see that the Branch_C integrated in to the master branch with keeping the commit histories made on Branch_C.

 

2. Squash and merge: squash and merge Branch_A

In this step, we'll continue to execute the merge operation with the Developer A account. When you want to execture the merge operation by yourself, you can create a Pull Request on your own and executre the merge operation.

 Action by Developer A

1) Create a new Pull Request from the Pull requests tab.

 

2) Select Branch_A to compare, and press the Create pull request button

 

3) Add a PR comment and press the Create pull request button. As Developer A exectutes the merge operation himself, no need to select a reviewer.

 

4) Select Squash and merge under the Merge pull request pull down.

 

5) Press the Confirm squash and merge button. The squash merge is executed.

 

6) Check the commit history on the master branch. You can see that the Branch_A was squashed and merged. As the original commits are squashed, you cannot see the original commits details (A1LA, A2LA). 

 

3. Rebase and merge: rebase and merge Branch_B

Finally, execute rebase and merge Branch_B. We continue the operation with Developer A account.

 Action by Developer A

1) Follow the same process as the previous step until the merge option selection. Select Rebase and merge in the merge option list.

 

2) Press the Confirm rebase and merge button. Rebase and merge are executed.

 

3) Check the commit history on the master branch. You can see that the Branch_B was rebased and merged (became the HEAD of the master branch).

 

4. Update the local branches

All the operations on this page were made on GitHub platform throught the web browser. The changes have not been syncronized in the Local Repositories. In this step, syncronize the changes made on the Remote Repository into Developer A and Developer B's Local Repositories.

 Action by Developer A

First, check the latest status of the master branch. You can see that the branch is not updated yet.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout master
git log --oneline

 Command Line - RESPONSE

de2bca2 (HEAD -> master) M3LA
a4e2c2f M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

Run the pull command and check the log with the "--graph" option to see the latest commit tree.

 Command Line - INPUT

git pull origin master
git log --oneline --graph

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* 5f5c4e6 (HEAD -> master, origin/master) B1LA
* c850bb3 Branch a (#2)
*   61ace59 Merge pull request #1 from bloovee/Branch_C
|\  
| * 56e6a45 (origin/Branch_C) C4LB
| * 884d938 C3LB
| * 1fbe7ca C2LB
| * 8c3d8a0 C1LB
|/  
* de2bca2 M3LA
* a4e2c2f M2RA
* ee8f530 M1LA

 

Repeat the same process for Developer B.

 Action by Developer B

 First, check the latest status of the master branch. You can see that the branch is not updated yet.

 Command Line - INPUT

git checkout master
git log --oneline

 Command Line - RESPONSE

de2bca2 (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD) M3LA
a4e2c2f M2RA
ee8f530 M1LA

Run the pull command and check the log with the "--graph" option to see the latest commit tree.

 Command Line - INPUT

git pull origin master
git log --oneline --graph

 Command Line - RESPONSE

* 5f5c4e6 (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD) B1LA
* c850bb3 Branch a (#2)
*   61ace59 Merge pull request #1 from bloovee/Branch_C
|\  
| * 56e6a45 (origin/Branch_C, Branch_C) C4LB
| * 884d938 C3LB
| * 1fbe7ca C2LB
| * 8c3d8a0 C1LB
|/  
* de2bca2 M3LA
* a4e2c2f M2RA
* ee8f530 M1LA

fields.content:

TOPICS

  1. GitHub Issues Introduction
  2. Git Key Commands and GitHub Key Features
  3. Git & GitHub Glossaries

fields.content: xxxx

fields.title: Git Key Commands and GitHub Key Features
fields.content:
On this page, we summarize Git key command and GitHub key features covered in chapter 3 to chapter 7.

Chapter 3. Git & GitHub Initial Settings:

  • $ git config is used when you register (or change) key user settings in the Git system. For example, you can do the following with this command
    • Register your user name and email address
    • Register a text editor
    • Check configured settings
    • Clear configured settings

 

Chapter 4. Launch Git Project:

  • $ git init command is when initiating a Git project by creating a new Local Repository in the current directory.

  • $ git clone command is used to create a link with a Remote Repository and bring the project directory from the remote repository with commit histories to your local computer. This command is used only the first time you bring the project directory to your local computer. The $ git clone command establishes a connection between the Remote Repository and your local computer by registering the URL to define the location of the Remote Repository onto your computer. Once the connection is established, you can Pull or Fetch the Remote Repository.

  • Fork is a feature provided by GitHub used to create a replica of a Remote Repository on GitHub. After implementing Fork, the replicated repository will be separated from the original repository. You can modify codes in the replicated repository on your own without permission from the owners of the original repository (within the software license agreement, if any). Fork is not a git command. It is executed on the GitHub website. Go to the GitHub site and find the repository which you want to create a replica of. There is a Fork button on the Remote Repository page. Press the Fork button to implement Fork.

 

Chapter 5. Edit & Commit:

  • $ git add: with this command, you can add files to the Staging Area (INDEX), where you can prepare and check files to register in your Local Repository. 
  • $ git status: with this command, you can see the status of the Working Tree (working directory) and the Staging Area (INDEX). This status lets you see which changes have been staged, which haven't, and which files aren't being tracked by Git. 
  • $ git commit: with this command, you can register files in your Local Repository. Once the files are registered by this command, you can retrieve the saved version of the set of files anytime.
  • $ git log: with this command, you can check the infomation of the commit history of the repository
  • $ git diff: with this command, you can check differences among the Working Tree, Staging Area (INDEX) and commit histories.
  • $ git restore: with this command, you can bring your working tree back to the latest commit or a specific commit. This command is useful when you want to clear your edits and go back to a cleaner version.
  • $ git rm: with this command, you can delete files or directories under the Working Tree and the Staging Area (INDEX). When you want to reflect the deleted status as a formal version, you need to create another commit. 
  • $ git reset: with this command, you can reset the Staging Area (INDEX) or change commit histories with or without changing the contents of your local files. 

 

Chapter 6. Work With Branches:

  • $ git branch: this command is a multi-use command. For example, it is used for creating a new branch, checking branch status and deleting an unused branch.
  • $ git checkout: with this command, you can switch your current branch to a selected branch. 
  • $ git switch: with this command, you can get the same result as $ git checkout. It is a newly introduced command as a substitute of the $ git checkout command.
  • $ git merge: with this command, you can merge branches. The merge operation can be done through a Remote Repository on the GitHub website. Merge operation on GitHub will be explained in the next chapter.
  • $ git rebase: with this command, you can reapply commits on top of another base branch. This command is useful when you want to streamline the commits diverged into multiple branches. The rebase operation can also be done through a Remote Repository on the GitHub website. It is an option of the merge-feature of GitHub.
  • $ git stash: with this command, you can separately manage WIP (Work In Progress) codes. When you want to switch the current branch in the middle of editing the Working Tree, the edits can prevent from switching the current branch. In that case, this command is useful. The stashed lines of code are parked somewhere temporarily.

 

Chapter 7. Remote Collaboration:

  • $ git remote: this command is a multi-use command relating to manage a Remote Repository. For example, with the $ git remote add command, you can establish a link between a Remote
    Repository and a Local Repository. The git remote -v command shows the status of the link.
  • $ git push: with this command, you can upload project directories and files along with commit histories for a designated branch from your computer to a Remote Repository
  • $ git pull: with this command, you can download project directories and files along with commit histories for a designated branch from a Remote Repository. This command also merges the downloaded branch with an existing branch under the Local Repository.
  • $ git fetch: with this command, you can obtain the latest Remote Repository information and store it in your local computer. This command doesn't enforce merge branches in the Local Repository. If you want to update the Local Repository, you need to run the $ git merge or $ git checkout command. 
  • Pull request: this feature is used to ask a reviewer to review your edits. It is especially used when you want to ask the reviewer to merge your branch (a topic branch) to the main branch (e.g., master branch).
  • Merge: this feature gives similar functionality as the $ git merge command and the $ git rebase command. You can execute merge or rebase operations on the GitHub website. There are three merge approaches. 1) Create a merge commit, 2) Squash and merge, 3) Rebase and merge.
